content:
y 2, 2016
 Dust: An Elysian Tail  Story and Characters: 9/10 Dust: AET has one of the most engaging stories I've ever had the pleasure to experience. Characters are varied and all have some special quirks that make them all memorable. The dialogues in this game have these "quirks" just the right amount to make these characters seem more like individuals that you are interested in rather than just a squad of generic beings that you come across and smash A to skip the dialogue as fast as you can. Voice acting is great overall but at times could be heard that some of the voices weren't necessarily by a well-known professional, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but definitely noticable. Gameplay: 8/10 There is not much to say about the gameplay. Quite generic "smash buttons until baddies disappear". There is a special "move" called DUST STORM that you get quite early on and that is probably what you'll be spamming for the next 8 hours or so. I played the game on NORMAL difficulty and I would suggest NORMAL for this game if you're looking to play it for the story, since it has some of the epic moments of "Oh god. I'm gonna die soon but so is the enemy" but it also makes moving between areas easier and more relaxed since you don't have to spend 10 minutes per group of enemies. Graphics: 8.5/10 This game isn't filled with a billion small particle effects or four tons of bloom and still managed to amaze me in nearly every area I went to. The cutscenes have a charming hand-drawn look to them that is beautifully executed and that makes them nothing to sneeze at. Music: 10/10 Down right amazing. The music always fit the feeling I had while playing. Epic soundtrack. Can't say much more than that.You'll most likely get 8-12 hours out of the campaign but will probably get 20+ hours if you plan to 100% everything and get all achievements (I don't know for sure, haven't done that yet) . Overall: 9/10 This is definitely a game that I will remember and will most likely play through again in the future. I'd definitely say this is one of the best games I've played recently, and even one of the best I've ever played. Even though the gameplay aspect becomes quite frustratingly repetitive towards the end, the story kept my interest in the game very high. I definitely suggest picking this up if you're looking for an engaging story-driven game with beautiful visuals that is not too hard for a casual gamer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2014
												Developing video games is tough, even from the outside that seems obvious. It's not impossible, but it's one hell of a challenge, one that takes patience, time and talent to name just a few of the requirements to make it in the industry. So designer Dean Dodrill's accomplishments with Dust: An Elysian Tail is one to be applauded. Having developed the vast majority of this charming action adventure game himself, it's clear throughout that this is Dean's baby, resulting in a game that's beautiful, fun and one of the most captivating 2D side-scrollers I've played in years.Dust: An Elysian Tail tells the story of Dust, a being with little knowledge of his past or his own identity. He's Awaken from slumber by a talking floating sword called Ahrah and the swords protectorate Fidget, a flying bat slash cat creature thing. This strange partnership must band together to help Dust figure out both his past and future in the lands of Falana, which have been beaten down by the terrors and horrors of war. For a story, it's one that nicely contrasts against much of the games visual design and isn't afraid to touch on some mature story points from the death and killing of innocents to the terrible physical and mental impact of war on those that survive it. I found myself surprised by the direction taken by the story till the very end and it's an area of the game that held strong throughout resulting in a story that benefits in developing the world as much as it keeps the tale chugging along.Now upon it's release Dust received some criticism for its art style, which to some degree I can understand. It's most certainly not an ugly game by any regard, the wonderful 2D landscapes are gorgeous with an impressive level of attention given to almost every level of the game, but some might find themselves turned off by the furry like characters that popular the lands of Falana. Personally I was charmed with it's interesting cast of characters all voiced to an high degree resulting in a world that's more interesting than you'd think it had any right to be. Dust's small but useful sidekick Fidget in particular is an high point thanks to some great dialogue and cute voice work by Kimlinh Tran. It all results in an high level of polish that you can't help but admire considering the time and effort put in by the mainly one man development team.An action packed side-scroller, Dust is primarily inspired by the likes of Castlevania and Metroid with it's walled off sections that make traversal and map navigation part of the challenge. Anyone who's spent time with the genre will feel right at home here thanks to the fact that navigation is a breeze and finding all those treasures and secrets as always been part of the real fun with these sorts of games. An Elysian Tail is no different and while you'll be traveling a large variety of regions, you'll find himself traveling back to lands you've already visited in search of treasures that were once inaccessible to you. On his journey Dust will have access to new and varied powers that can be used to discover and access these treasures and even be used in combat. The powers range from the ability to slide under walls to secondary jumps to be able to double jump and reach higher points in the landscape. What's great about all these powers is that there just as effective in combat as they are when platforming.Falana is a land filled with a nice variety of baddies to swing your magical sword at and thankfully combat remains fun for the most part, even if I did find myself button mashing most of the time. Enemies will reappear if you exit and reenter an area so it's possible to grind your skills and levels if you wish. One note I'd add is that on normal, Dust can be a little to easy and whilst there are a few challenges here and there, it's not exactly a difficult game so you might want to consider playing are a harder difficulty level if that's your thing. Leveling up and enhancing skills is a fun addition, as is the ability to craft and equip new items to wear, although some might find crafting items becomes a nuisance once you near the end. All that said, every gameplay mechanic at work plays well together resulting in an highly polished experience and one I had fun with until the very end.So Dust: An Elysian Tail is an impressive achievement by Dean Dodrill and his team of various contributors in the two years of development. It's an impressive achievement because you wouldn't guess that the majority of it's development was worked on by only one man. Rich in content, visually beautiful and sounding great, not to mention a story that's more memorable than you've come to expect from the genre, it all results in a game I'd highly recommend you play for yourself, even if you're turned off by the character designs. Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the most charming games I've played in quite a while.

content:
, 2014
												Sidescrolling RPG with very clean, beautiful graphics. Really good soundtrack, although it doesn't really stand out while playing. The character designs and their personalities are really well done, as is the dialogue. Lots of funny moments involving the main character (Dust) and his side-kick (Fidget.) The story is good but isn't very deep. Most of the gameplay revolves around sidequests or things not super directly related to the story's main premise. It's not until the last chapter that you even really learn the spoilers.The combat is very smooth and fluid, although it really starts to get repetitive a little over half-way in. The only real reason I didn't notice it so much is that you can build hits together for combos, and so I tended to always try to beat my previous record during fights. There's only a tiny bit of variation to the combat later on in the game, but it feels like it's introduced a bit too late and isn't all that different and exciting. I would have really liked a more complex system with more variations, but the combat is still really good just due to how smooth it is. The only negative I really have about the combat is that the game will often orient your characters automatically towards  an enemy or nearby object... so you'll be fighting something or trying to move into a specific position, and your character will somewhat auto-lock onto the thing it thinks you're trying to attack. It's fairly frustrating when it causes you to get hit during combat and break your combo.The last chapter drags on for an extremely long time as far as gameplay goes... it's a lot of fighting over and over. The story during this chapter really ramps up though, so it urges you to press on to see what it all means. The last boss battle is too ridiculous and drags on far beyond even the most patient person's attention span. It reminds me of Cave Story, where the game's flow is very well done, and ramps up as you progress.. but then the final battle is just way over the top to the point of being much harder than any other part of the game, and really frustrating.There are lots of things hidden away for you to find, namely keys that are used to unlock chests with goodies inside, and a bunch of "friends" which are just cameos of characters from other games. They're all fairly well hidden and it's fun to figure out how too get to keys that are just out of reach.Overall, this is a really well done game with a sizeable amount of gameplay. If you're trying to 100% it, you will spend many more hours trying to perfect  the challenge areas and get all the collectables.

content:
19
												Just a quick note at start: I may forget mentioning something in this review, I played the game over 2 years ago when which was the time when I was not reviewing any games. But now that I started making reviews as a small hobby, I figured I'd review this game too.Anyway, let's get into it:Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing game, a masterpiece and one of the best games I've ever played. It's a 2d game (by that I mean there's only left, right, up and down). You're playing as Dust, awakening in a forest, not aware of what happened to you or what you're doing there. You meet a little creature that I would describe as bat-squirrel called Fidget, who will be your companion for the whole game and with her, you set off on an adventure to discover your past. (There's a lot more in the story but I don't want to spoil it)Gameplay:Basically, four directions, left ; right ; down ; up, you are playing with an ancient sword called Ahrah and doing various combos with it by combining different keys, in order to get past your enemies. There's a lot of jumping, timing and precise button combining involved as the game can be sort of hard, BUT, you don't have to worry about that too much, there are a plenty of options, one of them being making yourself revive everytime you die, so basically invincible, if you only want to play for the story or find some part of the game too hard.I played on normal mode and easy (the invincibility one) against the final boss and the game took me 12 hours to beat, not to mention I did not do all the quests and didn't find all the easter eggs. So definitely, a lot of gameplay for the game's price. If you aim for all the achievements on steam it may as well take you around 20-25 hours, if not more.Graphics, design, art:Beautiful. The game looks exactly how it should in my eyes, the backgrounds, character artworks and everything fit the athmosphere. you have a lot of graphic options, even allowing you to move your "HUD", being a healthbar on the screen, so many details make the design of the game just perfect.Music is astonishing, I listen to the music creator's tunes to this day over and over, some of the songs are the most beautiful things I've ever heard and I don't think they'll ever get too old.But, the most astonishing thing of that all:The entire game (with the exception of voice acting and similar stuff) has been made by a single person! I know a lot of games made entirely by a single developer, but this is definitely the best one for me.Optimization/Controls:Perfect! I cannot complain about anything there. Can be run on a low tier laptop with no problem and the controls have no flaw.Summary:Pros:- Great story, tears almost rolled down my cheeks because of it after I finished the game (in a good way)- A setting that literally allows you to play the game just for chilling and story- A long gameplay, the main quest will probably take you at least 6 hours if trying to do it as fast as you can on easiest difficulty, if playing in non-invincible mode and wanting to do sidequests it may take something between 10-15 hours. Playing on hardest difficulty and for all the achievements could take around 20-25 hours?- Amazing music pieces- Well-memorable characters all throughout the game- Perfect graphics/art- Flawless gameplay- Great narration- Flawless optimization and controls- Pretty much made by one personCons:- I cannot think of any, haven't seen anything worth criticizing in the gameConclusion & reviewer's final words:If you like stories, games of this type, option to make yourself unbeatable in games, good stories (of course not everyone may see the game's story as good as I thought it is), just generally chilling gameplay combined with great tunes and want to support a talented game developer, then I'd say go for it. If I'm not wrong, this game is fairly often on a bigger discount. I believe I saw it for something like 2,5€ before? Don't take my word for that though, not completely sure about it though. If I knew what to expect of that game before, I would undoubtedly go for it even for its full price, would be worth it for me. Thank you for reading my review and hope you have a good day.

content:
29, 2015
A Paladin's Review: Dust: An Elysian Tail. A Beautiful Gem That Revitalized My Love of Gaming.Genre: 2D Sidescrolling Metroidvania with Light RPG elementsDeveloped and Published by: Humble Hearts LLC & Microsoft Studios. Platform: Windows, Mac & Linux plus Xbox 360 and iOS. Business Model: Base Game.Copy purchased by myself.Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsDust is a 2D metroidvania and RPG light game that focuses on combat, questing and character interactions along with some exploration and backtracking. Dust’s only weapon throughout the entire game is a one handed sword and a special ability called Dust storm. It’s a fairly long game ranging about 15 hours in length. Set in the fantasy world of Falana, Dust is awakened by the presence of Ahrah a talking sword that sets him on his quest to figure out who or what he is. All the while, Dust must discover new powers and abilities to traverse the 2D landscape. There is some backtracking when you discover new equipment and special abilities that assist in reaching new areas otherwise previously locked off. What you will find in these secret areas are keys (used for chests), chests, cages or other items of importance. This metroidvania is combined with a light-RPG system that lets you level up attributes with experience and equip gear to become a more powerful warrior. There's also a somewhat extensive amount of conversations to be had with the denizens of the land. Combat System ThoughtsDust features a lively aerial sword combat throughout the game. The combat system in Dust is extremely responsive and a real treat to experience. Dust has sword strike attacks, dodges and parry counter attacks in addition to a special ability. The main idea is to keep Dust’s hit chain, by striking an enemy as many times as possible, in order to increase his experience and damage. The aforementioned special ability is called Dust Storm. You will be using this ability a lot but it’s a whole lot of fun. It’s where Dust stands still on the ground (or runs around in the air) swinging his sword in a all directions. Not the most useful sword attack considering you're standing still, but that's where Dust's flying companion Fidget comes in. When combined with Fidget’s projectile attack, an ability that consumes your energy meter, you can pull off some impressive magical combos that will heavily damage all enemies in an area. Fidget only gains three different types of projectile attacks, each with their own particular strengths and weaknesses. Combined with some combo attacks that fling enemies into the air, Dust has a very fluid and dynamic aerial combat that is just really enjoyable. Oh and the energy system (which is also used for dodging) is regenerated by subsequent successful attacks and a high hit chain.Character ThoughtsFeaturing a cast of anthropomorphic creatures, Dust has a fairly rich range of them. Dust, the main protagonist, is assisted by the enigmatic sword Ahrah and the sidekick Fidget. Initially suffering from amnesia, Dust agrees to go on a journey to discover who he is and what happened to his memories. Which will eventually lead to fighting against an invading force that threatens to destroy everything in its path and protecting others from the side-effects of the war. Ahrah on the other hand is there to be...enigmatic. He won’t straight talk all that often and clearly knows more than he’s letting on. You’ll either like or dislike him, which can also be said about Fidget. The guardian of Ahrah, this high-pitched sidekick promises to be either endearing or annoying to most players. I personally found her endearing with the jokes, references and fourth-wall breaking along with her steadfast friendship with Dust. I can understand though if many won’t find her so amusing. PC Settings & Audio/VideoDust has one of the best customizable settings option menus I’ve seen for a 2D metroidvania. This is the standard all developers should meet when publishing a PC game, especially when porting from consoles. You’ve got all the choices necessary for resolution options. Full-screen is on/off. It would have been nice to see a fullscreen windowed mode but oh well. It does allow for up to 120FPS though you’ll have to disable the in-game V-Sync and force it outside the game. Depth of field, post processing (bloom, motion blur and shader effects) and weather effects can be turned on or off to improve performance. Anti-aliasing settings can’t be messed with but whatever default is being implemented, it works well. There’s variable refresh on/off otherwise known as v-sync. The character portrait quality (when conversing with people) can be set to normal or high. The HUD can also be adjusted to suit your needs and there’s even a color blind mode. Dust works optimally with a controller (whose vibration can be turned off) but you can get by with mouse and keyboard. Mouse and keyboard can have their keys rebound. As far as performance is concerned, Dust is rock solid and I haven’t had any bugs or crashing problems. Dust has an excellent soundtrack by Hyperduck Soundworks. I continually relisten to it over and over again and it still rates as one of my favorite game soundtracks. It features an instrumental/orchestral collection of tracks that range from calm and thoughtful up to powerful and epic. I get emotional every time I hear it again. I would recommend picking it up on their Bandcamp page[hyperduck.bandcamp.com]. Visually, Dust features an excellent animated style in the same vein as Disney classics of old, with a cast of anthropomorphic characters in a far flung fantasy land. With a rich and fluid animation style, Dust comes alive. To the point that even the cutscenes look slightly worse than the game itself, funnily enough. There’s a whole host of different creatures and locations to be seen and experienced. It doesn’t cut any corners, allowing it impress the entire time.Final ThoughtsDust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful gem of a game even if it isn’t a perfect one. It’s a labor of love done almost entirely by a single developer that, frankly, should be the standard of quality all one-man developer teams should shoot for. It’s imperfections are minor ones between some of the characters being potentially annoying for some (Fidget most notably), the combat system is sometimes a little bit too easy even on hard settings and the crafting system often feeling pointless. Still, I feel like these are minor quibbles. Dust will forever hold a special place for me for revitalizing my love of gaming. Its highly responsive combat system, beautifully crafted visuals, enjoyable storyline and memorable characters sealed its award as my game of the year in 2013. Kudos that I continue to support to this day. Thank you Humble Hearts. Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

content:
2, 2016
												When it comes to RPG's there are several key factors that often serve to define and disparate each one from every other one. Naming some of these major factors would lead one to include RPG elements like World Lore, Expansiveness , Story ,Quest Design, Side Quests quantity, Exploration, Character Customization, Skill Trees, Crafting , Grinding, The Combat System and just Overall Immersion in the game.  In an era where RPG's are trying to Reinvent, Innovate and Push the Boundaries of such thematics to Revolutionize the genre and broadcast their distinctive traits and appeal, Where does a game such as Dust:An Elysian Tail stand? Ultimately the success of every RPG no matter what kind of revolutionary concept they bring to the table boils down to one simple attribute Execution.Dust:An Elysian Tail is a game that has every one of the aforementioned RPG elements, While none of these elements come of as prodigious or unique, The game however excels in one simple aspect, 'Execution' and that is exactly what makes this game succceed and a joy to play. Dust plays an 2D side scroller platformer RPG with a hack n slash variant of combat. As I mentioned above all the elements exist in a very simple form. Combat consists of basic combo chaining and just beating up every mob of enemies you find. Platforming involves basic jumping, Dodging traps and so on. The skill tree consists of 4 simple attributes (HP, Attack, Defence, Magic) and every level gives you the chance to increase any one of them by 1 level. There's the classic RPG inventory system. Questing mostly involves point to point movement and fetching for side quests. Perhaps the most noteworthy element of Dust would be the Crafting system, You only need to accquire a material once after which you can sell it to the shop which will restock the material over time. This saves an enormous amount of grinding which would otherwise be needed,When it comes to difficulty they game is actually fairly easy since your character is pretty much overpowered but beating up those mobs still feels enjoyable and really cool. I started out on Tough difficulty and pretty much had no trouble at all, Boss Fights are straight forward and easy for the most part.Supporting all these elements is yet another simple but charming storyline about a man on a search for his identity, His search for himself brings him across diverse beautifully drawn areas(Backgrounds) ranging from underground basins to snowtop mountains,volcanic lands and rustic villages. Accompanied by a small flying sidekick and a talking sword what else do you need in a fantasical story? By far the only complaint I have for the game would be that Voice Acting feels a bit forced at times but it is nowhere near an issue to hinder the game.If it isn't clear by now, The game is simple but the way all these simplistic elements mesh together to create a feeling of  fluidity  is nothing sort of excellence. Perhaps this fluidity is the main reason this game is so much fun to play despite it's overly simplistic and straightforward demeanour.8/10, The game is worth the money you put in.

content:

												Just a quick note at start: I may forget mentioning something in this review, I played the game over 2 years ago when which was the time when I was not reviewing any games. But now that I started making reviews as a small hobby, I figured I'd review this game too.Anyway, let's get into it:Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing game, a masterpiece and one of the best games I've ever played. It's a 2d game (by that I mean there's only left, right, up and down). You're playing as Dust, awakening in a forest, not aware of what happened to you or what you're doing there. You meet a little creature that I would describe as bat-squirrel called Fidget, who will be your companion for the whole game and with her, you set off on an adventure to discover your past. (There's a lot more in the story but I don't want to spoil it)Gameplay:Basically, four directions, left ; right ; down ; up, you are playing with an ancient sword called Ahrah and doing various combos with it by combining different keys, in order to get past your enemies. There's a lot of jumping, timing and precise button combining involved as the game can be sort of hard, BUT, you don't have to worry about that too much, there are a plenty of options, one of them being making yourself revive everytime you die, so basically invincible, if you only want to play for the story or find some part of the game too hard.I played on normal mode and easy (the invincibility one) against the final boss and the game took me 12 hours to beat, not to mention I did not do all the quests and didn't find all the easter eggs. So definitely, a lot of gameplay for the game's price. If you aim for all the achievements on steam it may as well take you around 20-25 hours, if not more.Graphics, design, art:Beautiful. The game looks exactly how it should in my eyes, the backgrounds, character artworks and everything fit the athmosphere. you have a lot of graphic options, even allowing you to move your "HUD", being a healthbar on the screen, so many details make the design of the game just perfect.Music is astonishing, I listen to the music creator's tunes to this day over and over, some of the songs are the most beautiful things I've ever heard and I don't think they'll ever get too old.But, the most astonishing thing of that all:The entire game (with the exception of voice acting and similar stuff) has been made by a single person! I know a lot of games made entirely by a single developer, but this is definitely the best one for me.Optimization/Controls:Perfect! I cannot complain about anything there. Can be run on a low tier laptop with no problem and the controls have no flaw.Summary:Pros:- Great story, tears almost rolled down my cheeks because of it after I finished the game (in a good way)- A setting that literally allows you to play the game just for chilling and story- A long gameplay, the main quest will probably take you at least 6 hours if trying to do it as fast as you can on easiest difficulty, if playing in non-invincible mode and wanting to do sidequests it may take something between 10-15 hours. Playing on hardest difficulty and for all the achievements could take around 20-25 hours?- Amazing music pieces- Well-memorable characters all throughout the game- Perfect graphics/art- Flawless gameplay- Great narration- Flawless optimization and controls- Pretty much made by one personCons:- I cannot think of any, haven't seen anything worth criticizing in the gameConclusion & reviewer's final words:If you like stories, games of this type, option to make yourself unbeatable in games, good stories (of course not everyone may see the game's story as good as I thought it is), just generally chilling gameplay combined with great tunes and want to support a talented game developer, then I'd say go for it. If I'm not wrong, this game is fairly often on a bigger discount. I believe I saw it for something like 2,5€ before? Don't take my word for that though, not completely sure about it though. If I knew what to expect of that game before, I would undoubtedly go for it even for its full price, would be worth it for me. Thank you for reading my review and hope you have a good day.

content:
3, 2014
												I have to admit, at first, I really didn't like this. Even right through to the end I found the characters and their art and voices to have an extremely amateur flavour. The entire thing seemed like a bog standard furry Flash on Newgrounds. Your companion especially is pretty much godawful throughout, with the occasional humourous quip. However, I persevered, and with a second launch of the game I started to overlook that initial shortcoming and start to get into what is in fact, a very good game. The settings and backgrounds were gorgeous and varied (why couldn't the artist that did that do the characters?) and I also liked the majority of the monster designs. The levels had a satisfyingly open feel with a nice sense of scale and immersion; I especially liked the zombie meadow level. The combat, levelling and crafting systems work well (although my completionist nature did seem to make my character rather overpowered towards the end of the game, making the final boss fight extremely easy), and the game has a decent amount of varied and interesting equipment to kit out your character with. While primarily an action game, I found many of the hidden treasures and their puzzles quite satisfying, and especially liked the secret 'Friends' and their bonuses. The hidden Trials were also quite a lot of fun to master, giving a little bit of extra to the game. I also found the story good with an interesting setup, although suffering from the standard aribtrary development stifling (AKA "You'll find out later because no reason other than it'll make the story longer").Overall a good an unique contender in the Metroidvania genre, worth picking up if you're into that sort of game and don't mind the characters and amateurish aspects.

content:
29, 2015
A Paladin's Review: Dust: An Elysian Tail. A Beautiful Gem That Revitalized My Love of Gaming.Genre: 2D Sidescrolling Metroidvania with Light RPG elementsDeveloped and Published by: Humble Hearts LLC & Microsoft Studios. Platform: Windows, Mac & Linux plus Xbox 360 and iOS. Business Model: Base Game.Copy purchased by myself.Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsDust is a 2D metroidvania and RPG light game that focuses on combat, questing and character interactions along with some exploration and backtracking. Dust’s only weapon throughout the entire game is a one handed sword and a special ability called Dust storm. It’s a fairly long game ranging about 15 hours in length. Set in the fantasy world of Falana, Dust is awakened by the presence of Ahrah a talking sword that sets him on his quest to figure out who or what he is. All the while, Dust must discover new powers and abilities to traverse the 2D landscape. There is some backtracking when you discover new equipment and special abilities that assist in reaching new areas otherwise previously locked off. What you will find in these secret areas are keys (used for chests), chests, cages or other items of importance. This metroidvania is combined with a light-RPG system that lets you level up attributes with experience and equip gear to become a more powerful warrior. There's also a somewhat extensive amount of conversations to be had with the denizens of the land. Combat System ThoughtsDust features a lively aerial sword combat throughout the game. The combat system in Dust is extremely responsive and a real treat to experience. Dust has sword strike attacks, dodges and parry counter attacks in addition to a special ability. The main idea is to keep Dust’s hit chain, by striking an enemy as many times as possible, in order to increase his experience and damage. The aforementioned special ability is called Dust Storm. You will be using this ability a lot but it’s a whole lot of fun. It’s where Dust stands still on the ground (or runs around in the air) swinging his sword in a all directions. Not the most useful sword attack considering you're standing still, but that's where Dust's flying companion Fidget comes in. When combined with Fidget’s projectile attack, an ability that consumes your energy meter, you can pull off some impressive magical combos that will heavily damage all enemies in an area. Fidget only gains three different types of projectile attacks, each with their own particular strengths and weaknesses. Combined with some combo attacks that fling enemies into the air, Dust has a very fluid and dynamic aerial combat that is just really enjoyable. Oh and the energy system (which is also used for dodging) is regenerated by subsequent successful attacks and a high hit chain.Character ThoughtsFeaturing a cast of anthropomorphic creatures, Dust has a fairly rich range of them. Dust, the main protagonist, is assisted by the enigmatic sword Ahrah and the sidekick Fidget. Initially suffering from amnesia, Dust agrees to go on a journey to discover who he is and what happened to his memories. Which will eventually lead to fighting against an invading force that threatens to destroy everything in its path and protecting others from the side-effects of the war. Ahrah on the other hand is there to be...enigmatic. He won’t straight talk all that often and clearly knows more than he’s letting on. You’ll either like or dislike him, which can also be said about Fidget. The guardian of Ahrah, this high-pitched sidekick promises to be either endearing or annoying to most players. I personally found her endearing with the jokes, references and fourth-wall breaking along with her steadfast friendship with Dust. I can understand though if many won’t find her so amusing. PC Settings & Audio/VideoDust has one of the best customizable settings option menus I’ve seen for a 2D metroidvania. This is the standard all developers should meet when publishing a PC game, especially when porting from consoles. You’ve got all the choices necessary for resolution options. Full-screen is on/off. It would have been nice to see a fullscreen windowed mode but oh well. It does allow for up to 120FPS though you’ll have to disable the in-game V-Sync and force it outside the game. Depth of field, post processing (bloom, motion blur and shader effects) and weather effects can be turned on or off to improve performance. Anti-aliasing settings can’t be messed with but whatever default is being implemented, it works well. There’s variable refresh on/off otherwise known as v-sync. The character portrait quality (when conversing with people) can be set to normal or high. The HUD can also be adjusted to suit your needs and there’s even a color blind mode. Dust works optimally with a controller (whose vibration can be turned off) but you can get by with mouse and keyboard. Mouse and keyboard can have their keys rebound. As far as performance is concerned, Dust is rock solid and I haven’t had any bugs or crashing problems. Dust has an excellent soundtrack by Hyperduck Soundworks. I continually relisten to it over and over again and it still rates as one of my favorite game soundtracks. It features an instrumental/orchestral collection of tracks that range from calm and thoughtful up to powerful and epic. I get emotional every time I hear it again. I would recommend picking it up on their Bandcamp page[hyperduck.bandcamp.com]. Visually, Dust features an excellent animated style in the same vein as Disney classics of old, with a cast of anthropomorphic characters in a far flung fantasy land. With a rich and fluid animation style, Dust comes alive. To the point that even the cutscenes look slightly worse than the game itself, funnily enough. There’s a whole host of different creatures and locations to be seen and experienced. It doesn’t cut any corners, allowing it impress the entire time.Final ThoughtsDust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful gem of a game even if it isn’t a perfect one. It’s a labor of love done almost entirely by a single developer that, frankly, should be the standard of quality all one-man developer teams should shoot for. It’s imperfections are minor ones between some of the characters being potentially annoying for some (Fidget most notably), the combat system is sometimes a little bit too easy even on hard settings and the crafting system often feeling pointless. Still, I feel like these are minor quibbles. Dust will forever hold a special place for me for revitalizing my love of gaming. Its highly responsive combat system, beautifully crafted visuals, enjoyable storyline and memorable characters sealed its award as my game of the year in 2013. Kudos that I continue to support to this day. Thank you Humble Hearts. Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

ber 19, 2013
												What every other Indie game should've been. A fun, exciting and creative idea for a game that strays away from your typical Minecraft/Infiniminer clone and utilizes an art style of its own instead of your typical "SNES Style" graphics you'd see in almost every release that other developers churn out and brings out a story line and soundtrack that you'll remember throughout your life. This game maybe another sidescroller fighting game, this game still brings out a challenge to everyone and allows you to find secrets within the game if you're up for it. If you don't feel up for a higher difficulty and rather spend more time on following the storyline, they give you the option for a lower difficulty. For best experience, play it with a controller and not a keyboard. Be careful though, if you're using a certain move too much, you'll take damage. This may be a pain for people (like me) who have a nasty habit of mashing buttons while battling creatures. I recommend this to anyone who's looking for an indie game that doesn't play off the fame of Minecraft and the likes.

												tl:dr - BUY IT.I'm a gamer for more than 15 years and this is one of my favorite games of all time.Graphics - Absolutely gorgeous. Music fits the graphics. Fighting system is simple but very enjoyable. It's fast, easy (From complexity standpoint) and visually appealing (everything explodes, shines, combos goes up to few hundrets). It's a metroidvania with a light RPG elements. Story is kinda generic, but it's satisfying, The only problem I had was how the characters looks like. Enemies looks relatively good, but NPC have that very cheap furry/cartoon style. I would rather like to see more "direct furry approach" or at least better quality of them  (shading, color pallete, more details, etc.). The only good looking NPC is Fidget (that flying cat/bat thingy... She's a Nimbat.). Characters are very good written. Oh, and Fidget is The Cutest character in video game I've ever seen. A want a plushie of her :3  (so I can keep her foreveeerrr....) 	 Anyway, Game took me about 13h to fully complete it, it's relatively hard on "hard difficulty", I haven't encountered any bugs or errors. I was playing it on Windows XP (Steam says it requires Vista/7). No slowdowns. In other words - Works good. Nothing much to say, really. It's a fantastic game, you should go and buy it. It's definitely worth your money.

												So, where do I start... Possibly amongst the best games I've ever played in my entire life. It has some minor flaws, including a bug in the final boss fight which forces you to fight the boos all over again but other than that it's a masterpiece, a well polished PC port and a fine work of art. The soundtrack is relaxing and fits the game atmosphere very well. The combat is surprisingly satisfying, it combines brawling with hack and slash, in other words I can say that this is a Metroidvania ARPG Brawler. The combos are pretty good and the attack variety is somehow doesn't have alot of variety but it doesn't feel boring. The story is pretty great and overall that sells this game for me. I'm sure that pretty much anyone can enjoy this game and if you don't feel like paying full price for it, wait for a sale and then get it. I got it during a 50% sale but now I can safely say that the game is worth the full price, but this is only a matter of opinion. That said, please buy and play this, support the developer and MAYBE in the future there will be more games like this one.

												10/10 Imo and I'm gonna tell you why.(I especially think it's worth a buy as it holds as much if not morecontent of most $60 single player games)-Graphics-I seen one minor glitch but it didn't hinder gameplay and it only happened once.Elsewise absolutely clean game.So textures vanishing,blur effect spazzing,endless screenshaking glitches.None.Everything blended beautifully and the cutscenes were no different.-Character and development-As much as I'd like to say story,anything that I say can be held as a spoiler relating to story considering you start off completely blind to the ways of this world.But the characters my goodness the development is fantastic.I've never seen such consistant realism in character personality and development in those who change as the story goes.The developer nailed it from amazing voice action,to perfect emotion in every line!Alot of people don't like Fidget but personally she's a favorite.She's only annoying if you don't like comedy reliefs going off things inside the game.Dust,the main character develops dramatically in his own away along side afew characters as you go through.Even Fidget.If you want great characters and story theres a setting in the game for players just playing for the view and...well story.There aren't alot of NPC but there are plenty enough to have their own voice actors,motives and cares.Has a actual "Village" feel to opposed to your average "run to town to shop and leave."-Combat-Fluent,smooth,extremely responsive.So responsive I went back to afew other games and almost thought I was lagging.On higher difficulties than normal combat is brutal,relentlessly pressuring and even fustrating at some parts because your first move can easily be your last.It doesn't feel like your fighting trashmobs you just run through.Feels more like most these enemies are boss minions.Unless you grind or over powerthem,it's gonna be a nice run for your money.The game does lack a solid defense when can be handled with parry system (holding your light attack to force a clash) or by jump cancelling/dodging.This is beginning stuff so no spoilers ;P It's harsh but it brings out the challenge later game.-Leveling system is fairly simple.you level up and you choose between Fidget,Defence,HP and attack.Matters alot in the beginning because it will define how you fight thingss.Which is great for diversity!It's simple,much like the gear.So you'll spend more time clashing than having your eyes glued to pause menu or wik looking for gear to farm.-Bosses-I know how people feel about it so I'm not gonna name.But...I would normally take a point off for this...yet I'll keep it legit.All but afew bosses felt very easy...like incomplete.Maybe it was my position that trigger a ai to spam 1 move.But I've only died against about 2 bosses.1 of which was my own fualt for being so hasty xD.Maybe I got bad ai that run.But the ones I struggled against was epic.Gotta see it for yourself though,no spoilers :P-Replay Value-In my opinion I say this game has medium/high replay value.Based off how seriously you play this at first.I cleared this 100%.I may someback and do it on the hardest difficulty another day.In the end this game comes out 10/10.It knew what it wanted to be and it was that.It plays great,story is awesome,your promised to lose track of time playing this game with headset on.It's graphics are fantastic and even I have to admit.This is nothing in this game that really complain about except 1 boss...not a spoiler but the boss is artifically difficult on a bull scale.But I dout that'll kill the fun of this chaotic game.I hope the developer does another.

A lot of people bash the game for being 'furre' but we grew up with Sonic the Hedgehog and a myriad of other furre enduced games. A beautiful game, a touching playthrough with twist and turns, you really should own this if you don't.

content:
3, 2014
												I have to admit, at first, I really didn't like this. Even right through to the end I found the characters and their art and voices to have an extremely amateur flavour. The entire thing seemed like a bog standard furry Flash on Newgrounds. Your companion especially is pretty much godawful throughout, with the occasional humourous quip. However, I persevered, and with a second launch of the game I started to overlook that initial shortcoming and start to get into what is in fact, a very good game. The settings and backgrounds were gorgeous and varied (why couldn't the artist that did that do the characters?) and I also liked the majority of the monster designs. The levels had a satisfyingly open feel with a nice sense of scale and immersion; I especially liked the zombie meadow level. The combat, levelling and crafting systems work well (although my completionist nature did seem to make my character rather overpowered towards the end of the game, making the final boss fight extremely easy), and the game has a decent amount of varied and interesting equipment to kit out your character with. While primarily an action game, I found many of the hidden treasures and their puzzles quite satisfying, and especially liked the secret 'Friends' and their bonuses. The hidden Trials were also quite a lot of fun to master, giving a little bit of extra to the game. I also found the story good with an interesting setup, although suffering from the standard aribtrary development stifling (AKA "You'll find out later because no reason other than it'll make the story longer").Overall a good an unique contender in the Metroidvania genre, worth picking up if you're into that sort of game and don't mind the characters and amateurish aspects.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												I could not bring myself not to do a review on pretty much one of my favorite games. This game is one of the best platformers I have ever seem. Or Brawler.. or RPG.. or all of them. It is really mixed on what it is.Now, the fact that, in my opinion, that you are buying a $15 (Or Regional Equivalent) that took 4 years, and only by ONE person.  ONE . (His name is Dean Dodrill, praise him fo what he created)It's backstory in sales that it was an XBLA Title, during the Summer of Sales (Or whatever the hell it was called) and it was ported to PC. Which, most say the PC port is the best because of how much its graphics are better and run smoother. Christ, I even am playing this on a laptop with max settings and it runs just the same with the lower graphics! Pros (Settings): Full on great graphics. Everything is hand-drawn, and the fact that there is just SO much great graphical abilities, it just oozes creativity.Great Controls. The game has easy-to-learn controls. LMB is to attack, RMB is for Dust Storm, MMB is for Fidget's Projectile attack. Don't have a mouse or have one of the worst mouses out there that scurries away before you plug it in? The game also binds a couple of keys on the keyboard when you need them! It also comes with Gamepad Support.Cons (Settings):No "low" resolution. It means that if your framerate sucks (Which I doubt it would), it can only be put to normal, and then you have to turn down resolution all together.Now, the gameplay is great. It has one of the tightest responses there is. Breathing on your "D" key would make him move mabybe 1/1000 of a millimeter (Not really) And it just has a great system for combat. It is simple, and easy to play.Pros (Gameplay): Easy to learn combat system. It even gives you a move list in the "How to play" option.Responsive Controls. Can't explain that further.No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Quests. Sure, there are fetch quests, which almost every RPG has, but it does it with a twist, either meaning you have to get a certain ability or you have to defeat a certain enemy and hope they drop. Or, if you are like me, you cataloug every material you have.Catalouging System. This system is simple. Sell a material that vendors don't have Catalouged, come back later, more of that come in. There are 42 items to cataloug in all, ranging from rare drops from strong enemies, to extermely common, *cough* Maggots *cough*, and easy-to-find ones.Pretty much a 3 basic attack system. 3 basic attacks. Swordplay, Fidget's Projectiles, and both combined using Dust Storm.Cons (Gameplay):A buggy "No Escape" system. What happens is that if a group of enemies are nearby, you can't move on to the next area until you kill them. Which is good, but the fact that you can just do a perfectly-timed Dash and go through it.Lack of weapons. Your only weapons are Ahrah and Fidget's Attacks, no bows or shotguns, or special little bombs. This is 45% good, 55% bad, as for the fact that enemies can kill you in the air or with cheap high-damage attacks with no block ability.The Story is a great narritive. It truly is. It's not a yiff and anthro fanfic like most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ would expect, but instead it is a great story of loss, death, and redemption. I rarely see how even the character is actually something else than he thinks.Pros (Story):A highly believeable story. This story is actually like as if you knocked your head on something, went into a coma, had terrible amnesia, remembered your bad deeds (or at least what you think you did), and redeem yourself for what you did.The furry/anthro undertone can be removed and nearly nothing would be changed but the mood. Things are usually explained. As I mean this, either what happens is explained through dialouge, notes, or the unfolding story. I.e. There is a large enemy known as a "Trolk", and they ae explained that they can only be killed by stunning them, mainly because how thick their skin and sheilds are.Cons (Story):Independent Voices. This is only reflecting the bad of it, which is the microphone and recording quality. They are actually different, some are obviously extremely far from their microphone, while others are actually talking in the right sense.No real "Choices". The only choices you really get are that, in a side quest, you choose to add poison ivy to an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥'s clothes. (Either way is an achievement). Sure, there is only a "Good" ending, but that means what would be the bad? Overall Score:9.5/10This game comes so close to being perfect. It really does. It is just annoying that you can't really feel fully immersed if the guy you are speaking to sounds like he talks in a very soft manner for a large person, or that it caught a small background noise. This game isn't meant for speed running, hence why some mechanics are in place. I truly recommend you buy this, because this is a masterpeice of a game.

content:
ry 2, 2016
												Probably the best adventure game I ever played in my entire life, the first thing you're likely to notice when you start the game is how it looks. Your journey begins in a magical glade, and takes you through poorly lit ice caves, the dead forests long, snowy mountain ranges, and more. Dust, the main character, and Fidget, your trusty companion that will help you during your journey, you'll travel through a variety of interconnected stages, fighting the enemies, seeking treasures, and unlock new abilities that allow to obtain previously unreachable places. You'll meet a group of animated characters that will give you quests or continue the story in one way or another, and all of them have voice talking. While the gameplay is primarily based around navigating the levels and engaging in melee combat, there are plenty of RPG mechanics in Dust as well. Defeating enemies and solving quests will earn you experience points, and each time you level up, you can pick one of four parameters to improve. You can also craft items to help you along the journey, crafting requires both materials and a blueprint, both of which can be dropped by defeated enemies or found in chests. Opening those chests requires keys, which can be bought at a shop or found hidden in the stages. Keys can be found in secret map spots, and sometime you have to resolve riddles to get a couple of them. I'm not saying that this is the best game ever made, but its not bad either so why not give it a try? Am i right?

content:
ry 25, 2014
												An entertaining journey for a few weekends.--------------------------------Pros: - Fun and fast action fighting - Very crisp look and the environment with its gorgeous sights will surprise you - Good interface, even though has some bugs - Story is rather good than bad. It has a small plot twist and not your regular good vs evil cliche tail--------------------------------Cons: - Voice acting is quite bad in most cases - The closeup characters in dialogs are too plain and quite silly - Gameplay becomes very easy once you get the idea on how to handle those punching bags called "monsters" - Balance is managed by sheer damage. Should've added more divercity to the endgame boss battles and enemy attacks--------------------------------Tips for beginners: - Play on hardcore. You will have some problems at the beginning, but don't be afraid to experiment. - Learn how to counter attack. It will take some time to learn the timing, especially with the first tree miniboss and those mothafrakking slimes... - Don't sell red crystals. Since monsters respawn after each load, it could save a lot of time for you. Also usefull for learning the monster patterns, without having to reload too often - Don't save money. Towards the end you will have over 100k unused gold. - You can't reach some areas. You should come back once you get the required skills - Max level is 60. You will be able to max all skills. Though Fidget is by far the best one. - Fidget is your friend. She will tell you (a popup when enter the area) if there is a missed secret on the map - Unlock "friends" from the cages. There are 12 of them and it will give you wooping 60% health bonus total. - Don't rush the game and play only few hours at a time. You will finish it in 15-30 hours.--------------------------------Overall a great Metroidvania kind of game that's easily worth its full price. It could use a little bit more TLC and depth to the gameplay mechanics and NPC's.

												For those on the fence about getting this, Dust is a Metroidvania style brawler set to a beautiful soundtrack and fantastic animation. Anthropomorphic animals may be a problem for some people since this is the internet- but you'd be missing out on a great game. There's about 10 hours of content in here too - pretty good considering the price. If you enjoyed Super Metroid or Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, then you'll find a lot here. The combat in particular feels very fresh, and I'd say is more engaging than the systems in those two games.  In the future, I can see this game being considered a classic of its time. Give it a go!

content:
er 6, 2015
												Very polish game. It has great combat and great art.Attacking, launching projectiles, juggling the enemies to keep the combos up, evading if you notice the enemy starting their attack animation, and parrying. These are the essential for combat. And Dust has polished its mechanics to perfection. It's a lot of fun doing all the above. It makes you feel like a badass once you start to get into the rhythm.But its a relatively easy game for action players. I've finished the game in tough mode on my first try. If you've played other action games like Devil May Cry, I'll suggest going straight to tough mode.I'm a completionist, so it took me 15 and a half hours to finish (plus 30 mins to rush a new game on the casual difficulty to get to a certain quest to get 100% achievement). But I've noticed a lot of ways to speedrun this game and I think it can be beaten in less than 5 hours if you don't do the sidequests.Summary: Highly recommended for the great combat. The game is very polished.

content:
y 9, 2014
												A true masterpiece of a game. Dust looks great. has amazing soundtracks, badass and smooth looking combat filled with a ton of effects, precise and well made controls, an interesting story and tons of optional content to explore.Dust itself plays like a highly polished metroidvania game - you make your way through areas, later on you get new moves that allow you to discover optional paths and treasures in areas you have already visited before.During your explorations, you will meet some civilians that offer you sidequests which reward you with additional items and experience points.This, ofcourse, makes Dust stronger in a variety of ways. Experience Points are self explanatory, you collect them and get level ups (level cap is 60), each level up rewards you with one skill gem that can be used to upgrade your health, attack, defense or fidget (fidget is your companion and can be treated like a magical stat).Every skill can be upgraded 15 times, but the game limits you in a way that your highest skill can only be 4 skill levels higher than your lowest one (your defense is on level 1, so you can't upgrade anything else past level 5).This sounds like a big limitation at first, but it helps alot by keeping the game challenging throughout all areas, otherwise you could just max out fidget and oneshot everything while ignoring all other stats.In addition to leveling you can also get stronger by finding / crafting / buying new equipment.Every area has different enemies that drop different items, and every area also has some places where you can buy and sell items. Enemies can also drop material items, those can be used to craft your own gear (if you have the required blueprints which also drop from enemies and from treasure chests).Equipment slots that you can fill are the following : armor, sword augment, amulet, 2x rings.Dust only has his sword in terms of physical damage, and if you equip yourself with a sword augment you will increase your physical damage output. the other items can also provide various other bonus attributes - automated health regen, better chance for item drops, more experience gain etc.The icing on the cake however is the absolutely amazing soundtrack. Rarely do you find a game where the soundtrack adds so much to atmosphere and fun. You enter a new area and listen to the music, and you are just like "damn, that sounds amazing". Even with Dust being an extremely colorful game, the music still manages to provide a dark and mysterious atmosphere when needed, which really makes it a joy to play. example track : 


YouTube™ Video: Dust: An Elysian Tail OST - 09 - The Sorrowing Meadows 

			Views: 63,384		

			Buy our music at the links below! - http://hyperduck.bandcamp.com/album/dust-an-elysian-tail-original-soundtrack - http://www.loudr.fm/release/dust-an-elysian-tail/RqVDh Original Soundtrack from...		

Depending on the difficulty level (4 available) you choose, you will get around 10-15 hours of gametime when going for 100% completion - and trust me, you will go for 100%, since the game manages to make backtracking and exploring a lot of fun.No matter who you are, i can only recommend Dust to you. It has been the best game i have played for ages (since the release of Final Fantasy 10 i guess) and you will definitely not regret spending money on this masterfully crafted gem of a game, especially if you like metroidvania games with stylish combat and great music.10/10 would buy again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 28, 2014
												An absolutely beautiful game with fluid animations and solid brawler mechanics.While there is very little in the way of weapon variety, you're still provided with a range of options for taking out enemies from your basic brawler combos to parrying and aerial throws, all of which are animated gorgeously. Despite being limited to one weapon, you do earn additional magic powers and movement skills, such as double jumps and wall clinging, as the game goes on, which help open up new areas to explore places you couldn't before.The majority of the skills you learn in the tutorial will be your bread and butter through a majority of the game. Thankfully, enemies later in the game do test everything you've learnt, so relying on a single tactic won't do you many favours, with some being only vulnerable to parries and others to magic attacks.Combined, the combat looks and feels great and doesn't outstay it's welcome for the 9 to 12 hours it takes to beat the game.The game also borrows a lot from RPGs with a level up system, side quests and a crafting mechanic, allowing you to build upgrades from blueprints dropped by enemies and found in chests. The upgrades usually add an additive or multiplicative effect to stats, item drops or health regeneration, which doesn't occur naturally otherwise.The entire game is fully voiced, which is an impressive feat for an indie title of this size. There are points where the dialogue feels forced, which can be chalked down to a problem with the script at points, but the main cast do a pretty spectacular job with their characters and help compliment the animation work nicely.If you have any experience with videogames in the past at all, I'd highly recommend playing the game on the Tough difficulty setting, as the Normal difficulty is far too forgiving. The Tough difficulty gives you a good reason to buy and use consumables without piling things on enough to make you ever feel overwhelmed.Mentioning the game is programmed and animated by one person is a moot point, but one that's bound to be brought up if you read up on the game on other sites or reviews. The game easily oozes enough quality and polish that, outside some late game cutscenes, you'd never realise or believe one man did all that work over four years.I highly recommned this game so much, that I even spent time writing out a review of this length. Hopefully, it's filled with enough information to make you consider trying it out. :)

content:
ry 18, 2014
												tl:dr - BUY IT.I'm a gamer for more than 15 years and this is one of my favorite games of all time.Graphics - Absolutely gorgeous. Music fits the graphics. Fighting system is simple but very enjoyable. It's fast, easy (From complexity standpoint) and visually appealing (everything explodes, shines, combos goes up to few hundrets). It's a metroidvania with a light RPG elements. Story is kinda generic, but it's satisfying, The only problem I had was how the characters looks like. Enemies looks relatively good, but NPC have that very cheap furry/cartoon style. I would rather like to see more "direct furry approach" or at least better quality of them  (shading, color pallete, more details, etc.). The only good looking NPC is Fidget (that flying cat/bat thingy... She's a Nimbat.). Characters are very good written. Oh, and Fidget is The Cutest character in video game I've ever seen. A want a plushie of her :3  (so I can keep her foreveeerrr....) 	 Anyway, Game took me about 13h to fully complete it, it's relatively hard on "hard difficulty", I haven't encountered any bugs or errors. I was playing it on Windows XP (Steam says it requires Vista/7). No slowdowns. In other words - Works good. Nothing much to say, really. It's a fantastic game, you should go and buy it. It's definitely worth your money.

content:
y 4, 2014
												This I can say without a doubt is one of the best side scrollers I have played. It's compelling story gives much meaning to pay close attention to the characters and the details. The combat is lovely, with amazing swordplay and detail in your every swing makes it all the better to participate in combat. The graphics are amazing without a doubt and becomes more detailed as you progress along as you're taken through amazing scenes from forests, to caves and mountains. And to finally top it off, would especially be the voice acting, without a clever display of emotions I would not have thought the same about this game as I do now. I recommend this game to others looking for good classic game with an amazing story, graphics and gameplay.

content:
er 21, 2015
												After just one playthrough, Dust: An Elysian Tail proves to be an absolutely beautiful game with a very satisfying combat system. The amount of destruction you can do by the end of the game is mind-blowing. It's basically an action RPG with the elements of a Metroidvania and it works extremly well. The game is also very user-friendly in terms of sidequests and treasure hunting, making a complete run of the game really fun. I still have a few treasures left to find, but I'm very close. The story is great, the soundtrack is great, and the characters are great. Although, I will say that some cutscenes do go on for a long time. You can skip them, but for anyone who enjoys a good story, there's a ton of dialogue in this game, despite the game being fairly short for an RPG. So, be prepared for that. If I had to say one negative about the game, it's the fact that at times, when there are a ton of enemies and attacks on screen, it's hard to keep track of where you are. This isn't a dealbreaker, but I did die a few times due to now knowing where I was. Overall, if you're looking for a very solid RPG with beautiful art, an engaging story and cathartic combat, look no further than Dust.

												First off let's get the obvious stuff out of the way: This game is gorgeous, and the audio is amazing. Okay.Dust surprised me with it's ongoing and expansive story, i really just thought it would be your standard 2D sidescroller (which i was perfectly ok with given it's beauty) but was gifted with this RPG-like story. The voice acting is on par with games like Final Fantasy, and the characters really resonate with emotion and believability. While the gameplay it's self isn't breaking any new ground, it is a solid sidescroller with RPG elements to the character progression. I firmly believe that if Nintendo had had the technology we have today, this is what 90% of the library for the NES would have looked like. It is an instant classic, and a game that i tell dozens of people about per day (i work in a call center and sell more Steam games than i do our own products haha. OOPS.) So take it from me, Tech Support Agent #52146, this game is for you if you ever played a NES game and smiled. Also, if you like cutesy creates.. the nimbat Fidget is just friggin adorable.

content:
er 31, 2015
												10/10I have played this games for hours upon hours now. The graphics, for being such a simple game, are very, very well done. The characters are fun, creative, and delightfully comedic. There is also quite a bit of story to the game.The puzzles are not the most difficult, but they are fun. The game gets progressively more challenging as time goes on, but it is still not difficult to play. So anyone that plays will have a good chance to learn the game while it is still simple enough to play.I love the story, I love the characters, and most of all I love Fidget.(Edit 1/2)As of now, I've completed both Tough and Hardcore mode of the game. I'm deathly in love with the story, and more so with the ending. The challenge in Hardcore is NOT to be underestimated and it is seriously something that demands the utmost effort. The mastery trinkets at the end (the x2 Attack and x2 Defense) I would recommend the Wisdom pendant (x2 Defense) for the sake of surviving against Gaius in Hardcore mode.  Hardcore genuinely presents the most challenge I've had with a game in years.I've put in a total of about 40 hours into this game. There isn't, I confess, much replay value unless you're a challenge ♥♥♥♥♥ and you just really enjoy burning your way through a game on the hardest difficulty. The Lightning attack is probably a bit overpowered, even in Hardcore because of how easy it is to distance-target enemies and just hide on ledges that they can't reach you on when you link it with DUST STORM.All in all, this is my favorite game of 2015. Absolute, hands down. I highly recommend this game. I've played "big name release" titles like DMC that present fewer hours of play time than this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 25, 2014
												After reading some positive reviews for this game, I decided to pick it up during the Steam Winter Sale and I am glad I did! The core of this game is the fighting and the fighting is great. You will be flying around the maps (literally) swinging your sword hitting enemies. It looks awesome, feels awesome, and is just awesome in every other category. The game also gives you several combos that each have their uses. Your companion, Fidget, also gets a few kool spells that can combo with your sword swinging. To be fair, let's throw in a downside. Fidget's damage is so minute compared to Dust's damage until the very end of the game where items give crazy bonuses to her damage. I really just used her spells for style (and it does stagger enemies for a little bit so that's always helpful). This game also looks beautiful and has great music. However, we need to address the graphics style. The characters are all anthropomorphic animals (I wanna say they most resemble a cross between a dog and a fox?) in an anime style which may turn some people off. Back to the music part, I would look forward to completing an area just to listen to the World Map music.The game has a wide variety of settings to customize to your personal preferences and your computer specs. There were a few moments (mostly towards the end) where my frame rate took a hit but with the amount of particle effects and action going on, it was understandable and it didn't last long. The controls are solid and can be played with a keyboard/mouse or a controller. The game even allows you to switch your input method on the fly and which adjust tooltips accordingly so. Now for a quick lists of things I did not like. - Fidget's damage is lackluster until the latter parts of the game.- You will almost never be at full health. I played on the Tough difficulty and was always around ~25% health the whole game.- Some monsters deal absurd damage (one particular enemy will just snipe you with it's tentacle and pretty much insta-kill you). No matter how much health or defense I had, enemies just seemed to kill me in just 1 or 2 hits.- There are some exploding enemies which resemble Bombs from Final Fantasy which are just annoying.- The healing system is questionable. You have a hotkey for healing items (food) which instantly refill your health. You can spam this button as long as you have enough food to eat. It makes the game very easy if you have ready to eat.- Last one, I promise. In some parts of the game, the camera just seems way too close to Dust. I wouldn't mind it if the camera just moved back a little bit so I can where I am going.(Please note that although these are things I see as problems with the game, the pros FAR outweigh these cons. These issues will rarely take away from the game.)

content:
29, 2015
A Paladin's Review: Dust: An Elysian Tail. A Beautiful Gem That Revitalized My Love of Gaming.Genre: 2D Sidescrolling Metroidvania with Light RPG elementsDeveloped and Published by: Humble Hearts LLC & Microsoft Studios. Platform: Windows, Mac & Linux plus Xbox 360 and iOS. Business Model: Base Game.Copy purchased by myself.Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsDust is a 2D metroidvania and RPG light game that focuses on combat, questing and character interactions along with some exploration and backtracking. Dust’s only weapon throughout the entire game is a one handed sword and a special ability called Dust storm. It’s a fairly long game ranging about 15 hours in length. Set in the fantasy world of Falana, Dust is awakened by the presence of Ahrah a talking sword that sets him on his quest to figure out who or what he is. All the while, Dust must discover new powers and abilities to traverse the 2D landscape. There is some backtracking when you discover new equipment and special abilities that assist in reaching new areas otherwise previously locked off. What you will find in these secret areas are keys (used for chests), chests, cages or other items of importance. This metroidvania is combined with a light-RPG system that lets you level up attributes with experience and equip gear to become a more powerful warrior. There's also a somewhat extensive amount of conversations to be had with the denizens of the land. Combat System ThoughtsDust features a lively aerial sword combat throughout the game. The combat system in Dust is extremely responsive and a real treat to experience. Dust has sword strike attacks, dodges and parry counter attacks in addition to a special ability. The main idea is to keep Dust’s hit chain, by striking an enemy as many times as possible, in order to increase his experience and damage. The aforementioned special ability is called Dust Storm. You will be using this ability a lot but it’s a whole lot of fun. It’s where Dust stands still on the ground (or runs around in the air) swinging his sword in a all directions. Not the most useful sword attack considering you're standing still, but that's where Dust's flying companion Fidget comes in. When combined with Fidget’s projectile attack, an ability that consumes your energy meter, you can pull off some impressive magical combos that will heavily damage all enemies in an area. Fidget only gains three different types of projectile attacks, each with their own particular strengths and weaknesses. Combined with some combo attacks that fling enemies into the air, Dust has a very fluid and dynamic aerial combat that is just really enjoyable. Oh and the energy system (which is also used for dodging) is regenerated by subsequent successful attacks and a high hit chain.Character ThoughtsFeaturing a cast of anthropomorphic creatures, Dust has a fairly rich range of them. Dust, the main protagonist, is assisted by the enigmatic sword Ahrah and the sidekick Fidget. Initially suffering from amnesia, Dust agrees to go on a journey to discover who he is and what happened to his memories. Which will eventually lead to fighting against an invading force that threatens to destroy everything in its path and protecting others from the side-effects of the war. Ahrah on the other hand is there to be...enigmatic. He won’t straight talk all that often and clearly knows more than he’s letting on. You’ll either like or dislike him, which can also be said about Fidget. The guardian of Ahrah, this high-pitched sidekick promises to be either endearing or annoying to most players. I personally found her endearing with the jokes, references and fourth-wall breaking along with her steadfast friendship with Dust. I can understand though if many won’t find her so amusing. PC Settings & Audio/VideoDust has one of the best customizable settings option menus I’ve seen for a 2D metroidvania. This is the standard all developers should meet when publishing a PC game, especially when porting from consoles. You’ve got all the choices necessary for resolution options. Full-screen is on/off. It would have been nice to see a fullscreen windowed mode but oh well. It does allow for up to 120FPS though you’ll have to disable the in-game V-Sync and force it outside the game. Depth of field, post processing (bloom, motion blur and shader effects) and weather effects can be turned on or off to improve performance. Anti-aliasing settings can’t be messed with but whatever default is being implemented, it works well. There’s variable refresh on/off otherwise known as v-sync. The character portrait quality (when conversing with people) can be set to normal or high. The HUD can also be adjusted to suit your needs and there’s even a color blind mode. Dust works optimally with a controller (whose vibration can be turned off) but you can get by with mouse and keyboard. Mouse and keyboard can have their keys rebound. As far as performance is concerned, Dust is rock solid and I haven’t had any bugs or crashing problems. Dust has an excellent soundtrack by Hyperduck Soundworks. I continually relisten to it over and over again and it still rates as one of my favorite game soundtracks. It features an instrumental/orchestral collection of tracks that range from calm and thoughtful up to powerful and epic. I get emotional every time I hear it again. I would recommend picking it up on their Bandcamp page[hyperduck.bandcamp.com]. Visually, Dust features an excellent animated style in the same vein as Disney classics of old, with a cast of anthropomorphic characters in a far flung fantasy land. With a rich and fluid animation style, Dust comes alive. To the point that even the cutscenes look slightly worse than the game itself, funnily enough. There’s a whole host of different creatures and locations to be seen and experienced. It doesn’t cut any corners, allowing it impress the entire time.Final ThoughtsDust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful gem of a game even if it isn’t a perfect one. It’s a labor of love done almost entirely by a single developer that, frankly, should be the standard of quality all one-man developer teams should shoot for. It’s imperfections are minor ones between some of the characters being potentially annoying for some (Fidget most notably), the combat system is sometimes a little bit too easy even on hard settings and the crafting system often feeling pointless. Still, I feel like these are minor quibbles. Dust will forever hold a special place for me for revitalizing my love of gaming. Its highly responsive combat system, beautifully crafted visuals, enjoyable storyline and memorable characters sealed its award as my game of the year in 2013. Kudos that I continue to support to this day. Thank you Humble Hearts. Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]
