The music is a sublime score that never fails to meet the occasion by offering immersion and creating the mood for a particular fight, or a jaunt through a spooky haunted house, or warm soothing tones for having reached a safe place and met new people!  The visual concept disturbs some people and takes a little while to get used to, if one hasn't seen many anthropomorphized animals before.  Every character in the game, as far as I am aware, is an animal in human form.  Dust himself is some type of white fox, I believe.  His companion, Fidget, is a flying red fox.  This adds a certain fantasy flare and otherworldliness to the entire game's setting.  Others may criticize the motif, but I find it refreshingly child-like and innocent.// Voice Acting and Story //Every line of dialogue in this game is fully voice acted, and it is all superb!  Some may express a deep resentment and critique for the voice of Fidget, which is quite childlike with a heavy lean towards sillyness, but I find it entirely appropriate and amusing for the character!  Dust is a compassionate hero with a dark past, and his voice matches accordingly.   Ahrah, your talking sword, is a deep and wise sagely type, who tells you all of what he knows while being ever prescient about future events.  The villagers are appropriately frightened, grateful, and emotional when the situation calls for it.  Scenes are quite emotionally touching.  Add to this the well-designed portraits, which have basic animations, nothing fancy, and you get the qualitative effect of a good book or radio program.   Very moving, if you let your imagination run even a little free.As to the story at large, I don't want to give anything detailed away.  At the very beginning, Dust awakens with amnesia.  This sets the tone for the rest of game.  Who is he? What was he like? Where can he find the answers he seeks? Who are his friends, and who are his enemies? Will he ever know the truth about his past? This allows the player a greater deal of immersion into feeling as though they are the hero, Dust.  Dust has no strong past at first to define him, so the character can place their own persona in his.  As his story develops, one finds that his past is quite complicated.  It leads to emotional revelations and has a deep and meaningful affect on the player, in my opinion.  A good game knows not only how to provide a story, but how to immerse the player within that story.  That you feel you are there, that is important.// Graphics //2-D isn't exactly new, I know.  But Dust: An Elysian Tail does it with style!  The sprites are animated, the edges are smooth, the effects of spells are spectacularly specular, with good lighting effects!  The weather and lightning add immersion, there appears to be a very low PC requirement overall, and this game runs smooth as sherbert on my very antiquated computer.// Gameplay //This one is the most important to many.  How does it play?  Like you wield an arcane blade of martial knowledge that imbues you with the power of a hundred champions before you!  The combos are rather simple and easy to pick up.  There are two main attacks for Dust, and one for Fidget.  The primary attack has a simple combo, and the secondary attack can be added to mix it up.  X, X, X, X is simple and effective, with a knock-back at the end that clears the enemies in front of you, giving you breathing room.  X, X, Y, Y is a straight-forward smash and grab, you beat them a bit, then run forward, and suplex an enemy, effectively attacking and knocking back any that are behind you.  X, Y launches the attacked enemy into that air, where follow up combos are endless.  Holding Y causes your blade to spin, which is an infinite combo in itself, save that it will cause you to heat up and eventually hurt yourself if you use it for very long periods.  One can also jump and use the blade spin, causing them to essentially fly in an arc, or towards the nearest enemy.  This allows them to stay in the air indefinitely, and literally shoot upwards into the sky if there are enemies nearby.  Aerial combat in this game is probably the best I've seen in any action platformer.  It's easy to mess up and fall, but with the right training, it's much easier to stay in the air and endlessly attack all of your enemies.  Ground targets jumped into your path? Press X, Y and you'll attack, then grab, and body slam them into the ground, knocking back, and shooting upwards, other enemies.  Allowing you to essentially always be in the air attacking, avoiding the ground completely if you wish.This brings us to Fidget.  Fidget's attacks are magical, she learns several spells as the game unfolds.  When she casts a spell, it is a joke, a lackluster affair, and it has no range at all.  However, if you use your blade spin while she casts an attack, it multiples the number of projectiles, and their strength, and becomes an AoE slugfest of doom for all of your enemies.  I play this game on Hardcore, and Fidget is the path to victory.  Her attacks deplete your 'Energy' meter, but this refills quite easily in a matter of mere seconds by slashing a few enemies inbetween spells. What this effectively works out to is this, you can fly through the air spitting pillars of fire, and endlessly launching enemies and decimating them to refill your meter.  The game's enemies are smart enough that they will attempt to jump behind your current facing direction, and will attempt to time attacks for when you land and when you are most vulnerable, at the cooldown on your combos.Add to this that there is a right and left dash that completely evade attacks, while using a modest amount of energy, and a parry system that allows you to daze and counterattack almost any opponent (this is actually almost essential for the stronger opponents) and you arrive at a game that puts many others to shame with the sheer fun of its combat!  The game also incorporates an inventory and equipment system.  You find items that aid in your base attributes, and offer some limited special abilities, like light radius around Dust for those dank, dark caverns!// Mood - Immersion //One of the most important elements in any game, to me; this game succeeds in all categories.   From the art, to the music, to the voice acting, to the combat, to the scenery.   You will travel from high-reaching statues of a bygone age of greatness standing like monoliths over grassy knolls and mountainsides, to dark and forboding swamps that seem quite full of danger, to haunted houses in sorrowful, barren, spooky and dark environs.   From snow to rain and back again.  Also, my personal favorite, caverns!  You will spend a considerable amount of the game in the underworld!  These caverns, in my humble opinion, are simply beautiful! In conclusion. Buy this!

28, 2014
												This is a great labour of love. can't find anything bad about it, i just like it and the idea that essentially (mostly) one guy poured open his heart for years to deliver this awesome game.This game is that good designed that EVERY big publisher/developer can only burry his face in shame. The options menu is astonishing, the tools the game gives you to set up your game tell you: Yes, this is a PC game. A REAL PC GAME. But... its not. It came out on console first and the developer took the time to port it REALY GOOD instead of dumping it on the PC as it is usual buisness these days. I mean ... the game detects if you use gamepad or keyboard/mouse ON THE FLY AND CHANGES MENUS ACCORDING, prompts the correct buttons etc... you can scale your ui, set it up etc... for a "stupid little" single player ARPG? Wow. Only 2 little things are missing and 1 is kinda major...1) you can't rebind controller buttons (you can rebind mouse/keyboard)2) You can - as of now - not change the language ... that is realy bad, because the game orients itself on your system default language and to change it you either have to change your system language or go into your install dir (of the game) and delete (/rename) your language folder so the game defaults  to english ...this wont bother you once dealt with once but with such an astonishing optionsmenu its... strange to be missing :)the gameplay is solid and feels good. I like the dialogue / voiceacting but thats a matter of taste i guess, this game is no gore/bloody/badass-game so beware Mr/Mrs Cowadooty.

content:
, 2014
												The game itself is alright, It could of used some more balancing though.Don't take this the wrong way, I have enjoyed the game and I'm still not finished playing it. I just wish I could disable the specified things below to add to the challenge of the game.- Dust Storm: Really this is the most unbalanced thing in the game. The ground attack itself is pretty helpful, But even that had the inability to protect you from behind. As a result enemies could still damage you, Which balances it out. But once you unlock the ability to use Dust Storm in the air, You're practically invincible. On top of this, It can enable you to skip areas and obstacles entirely by homing in on enemies above you, and being able to fly the to the top of the area. All you'd have to do then is find the exit.- Fidgits projectiles: All this really does is add to the already unbalanced Dust Storm, And make it even more ridiculous. This practically disables the balancing of the ground Dust Storm attack, by enabling you to attack enemies from behind. Now you're immortal on the ground. Use it in the air, And it's even-more-so. The aerial version of Dust Storm already enables you to deal massive damage to enemies whilst not taking any damage, Add in any of Fidgit's projectiles and you can quickly kill everything that moves, Including some bosses. Really it's possible to beat the entire game only using this tactic.Really these are the two major things, It's not worth listing the others. Aside from the issues I did enjoy the game very much, and I would recommend it to other people. I just wish we could alternate the controls and disable certain things.

content:
, 2013
												Well well well Dust certainly turned out to be quite surprising, despite it's cartoony simple appearance Dust proves that it can be a fun and engaging experience. The initial story premise relies on piecing together the identity of the amnesiac main title character and what lead him to suffer from amnesia, honestly there's nothing hugely interesting about it. The standard story structure is followed and you meet some decent characters on the way but there's nothing hugely memorable compared to other indie titles on the market. However Dust: An Elysian Tail's biggest strength is its gameplay. Dust provides a nice hack and slash styled combat system that has RPG elements in that you can upgrade your abilities and wear specific items of clothing to increase stats further, the whole system gives depth to the game as you hunt for the best loot. Also the combat flows very naturally in thanks to the gorgeous animations that never hampers the pace of the game, allowing it to become rewarding and engaging. The only minor quibble is that it can sometimes become rather limited as you are tied with one weapon along with three magic assist abilities, as a result the game can drag especially if you're revisiting areas for a specific quest. The games presentation is stellar top to bottom with the voice acting being fairly good (Even if Dust himself can sound like he's trying too hard to be emotional at times), the background and character design's being stellar and the performance running smoothly without a hitch. Overall if you're looking for a fun action RPG to get into then Dust excels over many of its counterparts and can easily provide you with 8-10 hours of fun gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 28, 2016
												FInished the game 5 minutes ago, tears still on my face, 10/10    In all seriousness, this is the most beautiful game I've ever played, the fact that it was for the most part made by one person just makes it better as well. knowing that the world you play in was drawn by the same person who coded the game just sets it apart form anything I've ever played, most games have so many people working on them and thus the original idea for the game is for the most part lost, but Dust: An Elysian Tail is the product of just one person's imagniation, and a very talented person at that. Getting it for $3 felt like stealing if I'm going to be honest. World:The game has a variety of Different enviroments and areas to play in, all carefully painted and seamlessly put into a playable game world. Each area has a different atmosphere, the forests feel beautiful and peaceful, mountains feel like a winter wonderland, and the lava area feels like the end of the world. while areas can be repetitive, they don't make you feel any less immersed in the world. I actually felt like I was in an endless pit when I was exploring the caverns below the village, and felt like I was in a deserted infected wasteland when I was in the sorrowing meadow. sometimes I just have to stop and look around at the drawn world around me and take in the beauty and effort that went into it.9/10Characters: All the characters are perfectly designed, you won't find two similar characters in this game. You have Dust, a, initially clueless warrior who must rediscover his past. Fidget, a cheerful and happy companion who has very cute voice lines and comments. and you have Ahrah, a talking sword who guides Dust and Fidget through their journey. these are the main characters, and they fit together perfectly in the story. There are many other characters with their own personalities like Ginger, who has a gloomy feeling through the game (you'll have to play to find out why). none of the characters feel repetitive and boring, and if there is a character you don't like, you're probably intended to not like them. all in all, each character feels unique and thought out. The game shows emotion in it's characters so much that I cried twice during the story, and I've never cried over a movie or video game before. not afraid to admit it either. There's also some amazing art of the world and characters that fans have drawn. just turn on google safe search, wouldn't want to get yiff'd, would you?10/10Combat:(I was playing on tough difficulty)Combat in the game is awesome, (though a bit easy to be honest). you feel like a badass flying through the sky pulling off 500 or 998 hit combos (I only needed 2 more ; __ ;) and trying to keep every enemy stunlocked while in the air feels rewarding. I'm more experienced in third and first person shooters, so I don't have much to say about the game's combat. While it did feel easy, the consequences of getting hit (when you actually do) are huge, having half your health for the next 5 or 6 fights with no health items can put you on the edge.The only thing I'd change about the fighting would be to put more health regen and making every fight start with full health, but in turn make every fight much much harder. it seemed to me that I was still felling the effects of getting hit once or twice a few fights back, even as I progressed forwards and I often felt "screwed' in a sense. 1 health, 0 comsumables and still a ways to go (this does make me feel genuine adrenaline whien I'm surrouded with that one health, a huge plus). The combat felt very good even when a ton was happening on the screen, enemies stunned in the air, fidget projectiles everywhere, dust flying through the air and the game still ran smoothly.8/10Muisc / sound / voice acting:I booted up the game and had no info on the characters, story, world or any aspect of the game, and the main menu music still had me feeling moody already. I was interested in the game's characters and story before it even started. the world music is also amazing, they really set the stage for the game extremenly well. the one thing I hate about some games is how the music tries to force emotion, but in this game the music goes with it instead. the gorgeous art and the stuning sound went perfectly together and created a world anyone can be immersed in, the soundtrack is probably the only music from any game I'd listen to outside that game, and the emotions I felt while playing the game are already associated with the music in my mind, making the tracks sound that much better. whenever something sad happened in the game, the piano always made me want to tear up, and I did twice. The sound effects are amazing as well, my sword felt heavy while swinging it through the air, deep whoosh sounds and high pitched wind sounds went together perfectly, and pulling off 200 hits in a few seconds also sounded amazing and satisfying. the deep bass sweeps when hitting an explosive wall or parrying an attack also sounded great on my subwoofers, and it added a bit of unique sound needed amongst the mess of sword strikes and explosions. The voice acting was also amazing, a bit exaggerated at times but where emotion was needed, it was delivered. little to none of the voice acting felt fake or pushed, and each character sounded different, adding to their personality. my favorite voice had to be dust's, he was able to sound relaxed, serious, and devastated at different times through the story. amazing work here10/10Story:The story is fairly simple, a warrior dressed in cyan wakes up in the middle of a forest with no memory of who he is and travels with a foxy companion to discover his past and save the world (TwoKinds anyone?). The story was good, but the characters are really where the game stands out. That's not to say the game's story is bad, but the other aspects of the game hold it to such a high standard that I'll probably remember the world and the characters more than the storyline itself. though the story does take an interesting twist later on. not much here, don't want to spoil8/10Animation:Diolouge Animation -The talking animation takes a style I have't seen in too many games before, the characters in dialougue scenes look like images being subtly scaled up and down, It's not a bad thing but It is very simple.8/10Combat Animation -The combat animation was awesome to me, I play my games at 60 fps but I had no problem in combat where the animations for dust only play at 24 or so fps. The reason being each frame in the animation is a drawing, a piece of art that I can look at. every once in a while when the combat gets easy I start focusing on Dust and I notice amazingly drawn frames of him, even in the heat of battle. 9/10Cutscene animation:No spoilers, but there are two Anime style cutscenes in the game, and they blew my mind. they took the focus away from the combat for a moment and focused on the art of the characters, and the story of the game, and they could not have been placed in at better times. I won't spoil anything but they take place at perhaps the two most cruical parts of the story. I know it probably won't happen, but an anime of this game would be amazing, if it were done in the style of the cutscenes already in the game. one of my favorite parts of the game here10/10Glitches:My game only crashed once. Other than that the game ran perfectly even in the heat of battle with many projectiles and things flying everywhere. The closest thing to a glitch I could find was animation cancelling duck attacks and being able to chain them together as fast as you could click, but it left your back open and wasn't viable in higher level combat. There was also a glitch which made fidget 5 times her size, which was hilarious, but it reverted when I went to a new area.9/10, nothing problematic here.Overall 10/10, amazing game that I would reccomend to anyone, even if the furry art style is a turn off for you

content:
2014
												Yes, yes, yes yes! I loved this game!Like many others have said, combat is indeed boring - it's a very specific style, so unless you're a huge fan of it there isn't much you can do to like it better -, and considering you get to combat quite a lot in a game like this, I was expecting to NOT recommend it, but... everything else was so fiiiiine I didn't even get bored for having to smash the same button over and over. Seriously, look at the screenshots here in the Store. The background is so damn fine you can just keep looking at it forever if you get tired of looking at the monsters getting cut.Combat excluded, this game is flawless.Artwork is GORGEOUS, the way the back and fore grounds blend is beautiful, soundtrack is actually very thought of (for a game of slashing monsters), voice acting is pretty good, writing (dialogs, papers/letters you pick up, story) is amazingly well done (did I mention this was mostly made by a single dude?) and other game mechanics make it up for the combat.There's one point where you get to the snow and it was SO magical. The snow in the ground will "react" in several ways depending if you jumped, if you just walked, if a monster walked, if you moved to attack... This is just one of the little details that made me like this game so much.Also, there's this "extra", which makes you go around freeing your "friends", and at the map you free them, the game changes to copy that friend's game. Like, when you're freeing The Kid from Bastion, you have an empty map that is filled with ground when you walk around, just like in Bastion. Or when you're freeing the little guy from FEZ, your screen gets cut in like 9 pieces all out of place, so you don't know where you'll end up if you walk off the screen. These were great!

content:
4, 2014
												Moderately fun side scrolling hack and slash plat forming RPG game. Played on the second hardest difficulty with a usb playstation controller and it took about 10 hours to beat it just doing the main quest line. About 2 hours of that was just grinding because I didn’t bother with the crafting system so my gear wasn’t that good. The enemies are not that difficult until you get to the last area. The greatest challenge came from the platforming as jumps were often very difficult to make. Your regular jump often does not reach high enough so you have to attack in mid air to get that extra height boost, but this makes sticking your landing in the right spot more difficult. You also often just randomly fall through platforms when you land on them which can be frustrating. I also had to restart the game on several occasions because I would just randomly fall through and get stuck inside of walls. The good thing is there are a lot of save points so even if you get stuck you don't have to restart that far back. The story line/dialog is kind of cringey, but I just skipped most of it. The environment looks pretty nice, but sometimes it is hard to tell what you can jump on or what hurts you as the background and foreground kind of blend in with the main area at times. I wouldn’t recommend buying this game at full price, but since it was included in the humble bundle 11 you can probably get it for cheap.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 26, 2014
												Dust provides a gameplay experience much like any other in its genre.  The control feel (I used gamepad) is fluid and easy to pick up.  The brawling mechanism is redundant at times, particularly when you are grinding to push yourself one more level on the tougher difficulties.  Animation in this game is truly something that kept me in it for the long haul.  The soundtrack is good enough that you don't really give it a second thought while playing, however its not the best by any means.  Characters in this game are likable (even more so if you are a fan of furries) however the story felt lacking in my opinion.  Slight changes here and there could have made this an extraordinarily memorable experience however without them I am left after two full playthroughs (120% completion) simply satisfied.  Great game if you can get it on sale or in a bundle.  There are some fairly interesting side plots to occupy time and for the purpose of extending game run time and this game has a tendency to give major throwbacks to old school gaming that always put a smile on my face.  I definitely recommend playing it through at least once to anyone who is in to this sort of metroid-esque game.

content:
, 2014
												The game itself is alright, It could of used some more balancing though.Don't take this the wrong way, I have enjoyed the game and I'm still not finished playing it. I just wish I could disable the specified things below to add to the challenge of the game.- Dust Storm: Really this is the most unbalanced thing in the game. The ground attack itself is pretty helpful, But even that had the inability to protect you from behind. As a result enemies could still damage you, Which balances it out. But once you unlock the ability to use Dust Storm in the air, You're practically invincible. On top of this, It can enable you to skip areas and obstacles entirely by homing in on enemies above you, and being able to fly the to the top of the area. All you'd have to do then is find the exit.- Fidgits projectiles: All this really does is add to the already unbalanced Dust Storm, And make it even more ridiculous. This practically disables the balancing of the ground Dust Storm attack, by enabling you to attack enemies from behind. Now you're immortal on the ground. Use it in the air, And it's even-more-so. The aerial version of Dust Storm already enables you to deal massive damage to enemies whilst not taking any damage, Add in any of Fidgit's projectiles and you can quickly kill everything that moves, Including some bosses. Really it's possible to beat the entire game only using this tactic.Really these are the two major things, It's not worth listing the others. Aside from the issues I did enjoy the game very much, and I would recommend it to other people. I just wish we could alternate the controls and disable certain things.

content:
2, 2014
												I am generally not a fan of 2d platformers; I got more than enough of them during the 8 and 16bit eras.  However there are some exceptions that are so well made that I can't help but love them.  This is one of those exceptions.  From the endearing cartoonish art style and decent idle animations to the *truly* excellent sound and music design and decent voice acting (especially for an indie game!) to the well crafted gameplay, this is a top example of the genre and worth a playthrough by anyone, period.  Take it from a critic of the genre, this is a new standard bearer for which other 2d platformers should be judged by.

content:
6, 2016
												For a long time, I had dismissed Dust as mere "furry" bait. An unfair judgement, I know. Anyways, I finally gave it a try because Hardcore Gaming 101 had the game in their "200 Best Video Games of All Time" book. Notably, they recommended Dust over Muramasa, a game I also really love. I'm really glad I ended up giving Dust a try because it ended up being one of the most enjoyable ARPGs I've played in a while. The story was engaging (and surprisingly even moving), the combat was satisfying and the entire thing is damn gorgeous. The only problem I have with the game is that I actually really suck at these combo-centric type ARPGs. The last boss battle destroyed me and eventually I had to lower the difficulty to finish the game. I hope to return to the game on a higher difficulty though and actually properly learn the combat systems. Anyhow, I don't know if I can praise Dean Dodrill enough, because what he made is genius.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2014
												To start off, I liked this game a lot, it had interesting gameplay and story. Graphics 5/5The graphics works really well with the environment that the story and characters were trying to portray. Each area looked beautiful with its paint style graphics. Also for the most part each area had something different to offer in the way of environment. Story 4/5I was extremely interested in the story. The story was pretty dynamic for how short it was. The main part of the story is Dust trying to figure out his mysterious past while he essentially helps people in need. Stories like this has definitely been done before, but for some reason Dust's story catched my interest a lot more then some others. With this said, the story left a lot of questions unanswered. For example, what was the background story for General Gaius? The story painted an interesting picture for General Gaius, but by the end, they just left General Gaius as the main Antagonist with very little explanation of why he did what he did. Also, the story could have gone two different ways. I think there could have been a possibility for two endings based off your choices. This could have made the story a little bit more interesting. Gameplay 4.5/5The gameplay was fun and rarely got boring. The game was a mix of 2d platform, rpg and action. You gain experience by defeating enemies and gain bonus experience depending on how high of a combo you can achieve. When you gain a level you are able to put one gem like stat point into one of the provided stats. Although levels were important it was mostly the abilities that you gained through the game that helped you the most in battle. The abilities you gained also looked extremely cool. At one point you were able to gain a fireball ability and if combined with Dust storm you were able to light most of the screen on fire torching your foes. With the right timing you were able to get a 1000 hit combo or more which was also very fun to watch and pull off. There were also many collectibles to keep you interested as well as challenge courses. I found the challenge courses difficult enough to get me angry after the 20th attempt which was fun but also a painful experience. The cameo characters were fun and sometimes difficult to find as well. These collectibles and challenges were not needed, but was a fun diversion from the main storyline. For the most part the gameplay was very well thought out but there were a few issues that I had with the gameplay. The combat was fun but did get repetitive at times. I feel like there needed to be more variety of skills to use, to keep the game from getting boring. The issue of repetitiveness was some what remedied by the shortness of the game, but I feel if the game went any longer I would have gotten very bored with the combat. Also near the end of the game I felt like I was overpowered. This may not be an issue with the game though considering I was probably overleveling while I was trying to get all the collectibles and finishing all the challenges. Sound/Music   5/5Nothing much to say here. The music and sound effects made sense for the environments and situations. The music sounded very good as well. Replayability 2/5Im trying to replay the game on a harder difficulty for the last few achievements but I find myself to lack the motivation to finish the game for the second time. There really isnt any thing different if you play it a second time besides the possibility to obtain some achievements and playing a more difficult setting. So a game plus option would have been nice or maybe a secret chapter where you can play as General Gaius and so on. Overall this game was amazing and well worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing game, probably one of the best games I have ever played. Lets get started then! The gameplay is AMAZING. The fighting system makes you feel powerful and is easy to get the hang of, but enemies can be pretty intelegent and hit hard to balance it out. Dust may be a hard game but it's also fair, if you get hit you have nobody to blame but yourself. Controles are responcave, but I have to wounder why the are optimized for left handed people. Nothing against left handed people, it's just right-handedness is far more common. Not that this subtracts from anything. 10/10 for gameplay.  Level design is good. You are never really bafeled on what to do next.  The first half half the the game has really fun level design, but it starts going downhill on chapter 3, the last part of the game is pretty good though. Enemies, while fun to fight, should have had a little more veriety, especially during the last 2 chapters. Most of the bosses merly meet the stadards they have, but the final boss is increadably good. Overall I give the level disign a 8/10 Music is... Meh. While the all music is very pretty, there are only two memorable songs; the song for the last stretch before the final boss, and the final boss's song. 7/10 The art is... Wow. Just wow. The art style is wounderful, and each sprite looks like it was hand-painted. Easilly the having the best grafics I have ever seen in a videogame, Dust is the only game where I can honastly say the grafics increased my enjoyment. Plus, there is a mode for colorblind people to deal with the few spots in the game where you need to see color. 10/10 for art. And now for the story. Which is great. Dust is one of the few games that got me to care about the story. The ending subratcs a little though. (SPOILER ALART!)  You die at the end. OK, I can see that sacrifice as being nessisary. But then you might not be dead? After burning in lava? Really? (END SPOILER ALART!) 9 out of 10 for story.Well that wraps that up. I would EASILY recomend this game. It's a little short, so if you get it try to do all the sidequests. Luckily multiple diffaculty settings triple the replayability. (Just don't do casual. Casual mode is for wimps. You can't die in that mode.) 8/10 overall.

content:
er 23, 2013
												I want to start off by saying that this is an amazing Indie game. The gameplay is smooth and fast paced - which hardly ever leaves you in distaste. The graphics are well drawn and keeps a consistent style across the entire game. Sound and music is well crafted also. Equipment system could see more improvements in customisation apart from purely modifying stats (e.g. affecting movement speed, giving your blade an elemental animation). The combat could see more variants in attacks and longer chain combos, including more types of projectiles to be shot. Story is captivating and the dialogue is humourous and enjoyable. This game can be finished in less than 10 hours if you blitz through the storyline, but unlocking everything will take a bit longer. Overall an enjoyable game - would recommend it to any platformer fan!

content:
ber 2, 2014
												A short, but likeable game, Dust provides enough story to keep you interested, and gameplay fast and responsive enough to keep you engaged. At times the writing can get a bit threadbare, but there are some refreshing points, particularly the main antagonist. The voice acting is very good, and while the idea of a tiny comedic sidekick can be a cliché, Dust's answer is well rendered, actually useful, entertaining, and, perhaps most importantly, avoids being annoying.Yes, the writing could have gone leagues deeper, and I hate to say it, but I was less than thrilled with the ending. Still, I don't regret playing Dust, and if there's more to come someday, well, this setting definitely has life left in it.

content:
er 23, 2013
												Dust An Elysian Tail. To put it short, it's an amazing game. The story is based on the character Dust who awakens in a deep forest with the Sword of Ahara and Fidget. Dust has no idea who he is so the three of them go on a adventure to find Dusts true identity.The game looks BEAUTIFULL. No matter where you are. The forests or the mountains. The graphics look great and never hurts your eyes. The voice acting is great. The actors perform there job pretty well and the only voice I get tired of is Figets because she never stops talking sort of like navi from ocarina of time. Graphics and sound aren't everything and Im glad to say that the gameplay is great. Having a metroidvania feel. You will destroy large groups of enemies with the occasional puzzle or platforming. Dust controls soo smoothly and attacks fast and quick. With Fidget you can shoot projectiles but with Dusks whirlwind ability you can make Dust and Figet extremley powerful and quickly defeat enemies. When you defeat enemies, you get expierience points and when you get enough you'll level up. This can increase hp, attack, defense and Figets abilities. I personally try to upgrade Figet first because dust storm is just op.You can do sidequests, craft items, etc when your not beating the snot out of enemies which gives the game some replayability. But it doesn't give enough.I don't really have anything wrong with this game. Except a couple of problems like one the game is pretty short it only took me 10 hours to beat the game. Two, its too easy. I didn't use a revival stone ONCE. And three I wish you could move faster than dusts regular dash attack. Because getting to one location to the next can drag after a while.Thankfully, Dust An Elysian Tail is a great game. Great graphics, sound and gameplay make this a title worth owning. Definately get this game while its half price  right now thanks to the winter steam sale. I'll give a 4.5/5 to this AMAZING  Tail.

content:
y 26, 2014
												One caveat before I begin my review: I got this game for roughly $4 through the Humble Store, so some of my opinion is emotionally affected by the price point. Now, onto the rest of the review!I've played a lot of 2D side-scrolling action games with RPG elements at this point, but "Dust: An Elysian Tail" stands out at first because of the game's impressive artwork. The backgrounds are splendidly rendered, and the character design is neat and well done. In short, Dust is a very pretty game, and it rates well on eye-candy alone. However, what sucked me in the most about this game is its fun, simplistic combat system. Whether you're a vicious button masher (like myself) or a combo-obsessive technician, you can get hours of entertainment out of this game as you wage your war against evil. I found that this game was easy to binge despite its simplicity. So, we've got a visually pretty game with a fun little combat system, right? Well, in terms of criticism, I can only really levy any on a single element: the story. The story itself, where you play as the mysterious warrior protagonist Dust, is a pretty straightforward affair. You attempt, with the help of the mystical Blade of Ahrah and its dimunitive guardian Fidget, to recover Dust's identity while helping to defeat an evil that has plagued the land of Falana for years. The dialogue and banter between Dust and Fidget can be kind of fun at times, but the dialogue in general can be very wooden at times, especially during the game's climatic ending. The story is simple (To be fair, this was a game built for the XBox Live Arcade) but, while easy to follow, it definitely leaves you wanting a little more in a bad way. While the game touches on Christian and Taoist themes (Shout out to my friend Olse for pointing this out to me initially), it definitely comes off a little more ham-handed than one might expect. The voice acting is roughly above-average, as it shines in some areas (particularly some of the banter between Dust and Fidget), while sagging in others. All in all, for spending $4, DAET was a fantastically fun Action-RPG romp with gorgeous visuals. Its standard price is a little steep in terms of game length and replayability, but not so much that I wont recommend it. This is a game that I really suggest you buy and try. (As an additional note, I gather than Humble Hearts, the game's developer, is a one man operation. If you take my recommendation and purchase it, know that you might be enabling another game like this!)

content:
y 14, 2014
												I was shocked, SHOCKED at how much fun this game was. It's not terribly difficult, but it is fantastically fun. It has some backtracking for loot, similar to Metroid, which is cool, although I know that a lot of nerds want to cry bloody murder whenever this happens, it's not TOO bad. Honestly guys? Why do you hate that so much? Either way, if you felt that backtracking is the unholy spawn of Satan himself, the game doesn't present itself with enough difficulty to actually HAVE to do it... If you wanted to like, make a political statement or something. Combat is fast and frantic, and presents itself with enough options to keep stuff interesting. One thing I found is that nearly EVERY strategy is a good one to accomplish monster murder, except not fighting, that is a terrible strategy. The story isn't going to win any Oscars, but its good enough to keep you interested, the voice acting is good as well, Figet is legitimately funny with her 4th wall jokes, so bonus. I only got stuck in a wall once, and that's the only technical problem I ever ran into, it was near the end of the game, so it already had me in it's smoothly animated clutches and I didn't mind too much. The game saves a lot, so if you ever ran into a bug it's unlikely that you would throw your beverage at your pets and start crying in the fetal position in your neighbors crawlspace or anything. For people who like bullets: -FUN-BUY-PLAY-YAYCheck out my youtube channel for a laugh (probably at my expense, but that's okay, sniffle) the link is in my profile.

												A game with a beautiful soundtrack, a lovely art-style, captivating characters, a unique story, ridiculously fun gameplay, deep character progression, great mechanics, and genious level design. Dust will please the completionists who want to spend hours getting all the little secrets and extras that modern games tend to leave out. I'm the kind of person who likes to seek out everything that is wrong with a game and then complain about it, because I believe it helps improve the specific game, as well as the industry in general, however, there are so very few things wrong with Dust that I shouldn't even mention them, really. Especially since they are things that I didn't like, but other people may enjoy quite profoundly. If you're thinking about buying Dust because you might like it, buy it, it's definitely my goty for 2013. Thanks for reading :)

content:
, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an action side-scrolling platformer game with a very fluid combo system and well animated attacks, giving the player a sense of simply being awesome in combat. I've played a lot of games, but nothing is quite as unique as Dust. The game gives the player the ability to move freely throughout the world, going to whichever areas they so desire to rack-up XP, explore or find hidden secrets in past levels. The story in Dust is one surrounded by mystery, the protagonist, Dust, starts off with amnesia and cannot recollect a damn thing about his past, which I know is very cliche but it suits Dust's story just fine. The protagonist is alway accompanied by a cat-ferret-bat creature by the name of Fidget (who is also the cutest damn thing I've seen since Tali in Mass Effect), who offers humorous dialogue and grants the player a ranged attack. To clarify: I f*cking love Fidget.Dust's combat system flows beautifully, utilizing a mere three buttons for attacks, the combat is simple but at the same time awe inspiring, easy to pick up on and very well made, when the player whipes out his/her first batch of enemies you immediately feel like an incredible badass and leaves you itching for more. As the game proceeds you acquire new abilities that complement your already formidible attack options and keep the game from getting stale, all the while maintaining a steady difficulty curve alongside an easy to understand XP and level-up system.Graphics-wise: It's an indy game, you don't come into it expecting mind-blowing graphics. Dust uses a simple but lovable anthropomorphic cartoon art-style that is both charming and outright adorable, but also dark and serious when it needs to be. All perfected with an amazing musical score and top quality voice acting. As well, Dust makes numerous quips at the expense of the fourth wall and makes references to other games, like Resident Evil 4 and Castlevania. The one flaw I've seen thus far is a somewhat finicky platform system. Sometimes if you don't land on a platform at exactly the right angle you're going through, which in a platformer game is a real kick to the groin.In conclusion: Dust: An Elysian Tail is fun, fluid, and highly addictive. I definitely recommend anyone reading this to pick it up immediately.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												It is rare to see a game like this be this well done. Dust: An Elysian Tail was made by one man, and the game has the quality of that you see with teams of hundreds working passionately on a project.The game itself is a 2D Sidescroller inspired heavily by games like Metroid and Castlevania. You will find yourself exploring a fairly large open world, looking for items, money, and powers which will allow you to explore areas that were locked to you before. The aesthetic style of this game is truly amazing as well. The use of varied colors really helps the world and its residents come to life in ways rarely seen in games today. I would find myself staying in areas long after I should have left just look at the visuals and marvel at how breathtaking the vistas are. While it is cartoony, it serves the game very well. I would also travel the long way through areas, ignoring shortcuts I had opened, just to listen to the music. The music in this game is nothing short of spectacular, with each area having its own theme that sets it apart from the others, whether it be a mountain pass that screams for adventure, or the haunted remains of an old estate with creeping terrors around every turn, the music sets the tone and atmosphere for each area very well.The combat in this game is a blast to play as well. You will find yourself slicing your way through hordes of monsters, with a small but very versatile moveset that never gets old. It is actually possible to have a fight last upwards of a minute, without ever touching the ground.Another point about the world of this game that I wish more games outside The Elder Scrolls series would use is the use of anthropomorphic animals. All of the characters are some kind of anthro-morph, whether it is a fox, rabbit, mouse, lizard and many others. I really enjoy this kind of thing, and it really helps the game stand out on its own, instead of falling into the tired fantasy traps of the overused elves, dwarves, orcs, and so on, which have been used to the point of being a checkbox for fantasy.In terms of story, this game is a marvel. The plot is surprisingly mature despite the E10+ rating, and makes a lot of "Mature" rated games look childish and infantile, and should last you around 11 hours depending on how many side-quests you do. I found myself genuinely caring for a lot of the characters in this game, while eagerly anticipating advancing the plot just to find out what happened next. During the story's darker points I was even moved to tears, which does not happen very often.For $15, you get a game that does everything right, and will stick with you long after you have beaten it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 15, 2015
												The game overall is good, story is interesting, visuals are really pretty, and the combat is dynamic.However, as much as I like it, i can't help but be irritated by some parts of it.Note, that partially it comes from playing on hardcore (highest) difficulty.In multiple places things like jumps and drops (especially while climbing on vines), need to be done almost pixel-perfectly. I guess you could ignore that if you can simply retry, but a problem arises if when you fail, you end up on spikes or some other damage-inducing crap.Also, on vines you just never know how exactly will Dust jump, which in many cases means spikes to the face..Undeniably the most irritating part of the game for me was a piece of Cirromon Caverns around the middle bottom of the map.It consists of 2 tunnels filled with spikes that you have to jump over, with mushrooms between them, that spill damaging particles. The thing is, that these mushrooms work completely randomly, and they give you effectively no warning - technically they flash around 0.5s before they do something, but it barely gives you time to dodge- oh wait, i forgot that YOU'RE SURROUNDED WITH SPIKES SO YOU CAN'T EVEN DODGE. And there goes half of your hp.So there's no way to predict that they're gonna produce these particles, it's hard to dodge them, and even if you do, you end up on spikes. Of course, they're technically a part of the background, so you can't even 'kill' them.While it's not impossible, it's close to being it, if you need/want to do it while not getting hit even once. You just need luck, lots of it.Oh, for some reason, if you take damage by touching the fire, you bounce back few meters as if you took a ♥♥♥♥ing sledgehammer to the face. Yeah.When it comes to enemies, there are 2 that are a real pain:Demons, who will flank the ♥♥♥♥ out of you and instakill you from behind (yeah sure, you can dodge, right? but only so much, and then you die). Sometimes they will also jump on you with a spinning attack and kill you before you notice them. Thanks for great camerawork, game.Necromancers, which you can damage only with Fidget's projectiles that use up energy, which is also used to dodge Explosive Zombies spawned right in your face by these Necromancers, that explode after 0.5s and instakill you..This is some bad level design.Don't play on hardcore, kids.

												A very nice game is every aspect.The story is well written in my option. Some cases you can see what is coming a mile away and some you don’t notice until it hits. It flows and should you want to stop the main story and explore some of the side quest it doesn’t stop you. There is only I do believe 21 side quest in the game. But some take a while and others not that long. There is a Yen and Yan ordeal all around the main character, which makes it interesting.Graphics have a neat art/graphical design to it. It is in a way kind of like an anime color to some areas bright and other dark. It is in I do believe a 2d side scroller is what it is called.Character design was also very well done. You will find yourself most likely liking the main character dust and his side kick figet. As well as many of the side characters. They all have their own personality set to them, despite there not being that many other npcs in the game. It makes it worthwhile to just hear what each on has to say. When leveling up your character you get to choice from 4 major areas to level up. My only complaint in this area is the fact that you couldn’t raise a skill more than 4 times without leveling all the other skills. You had to keep all your skills within 4 levels of each other. So you can’t just max out attack or defense if you choice. You will also find yourself looking for better equipment most likely if playing on hard or high difficulty. It has the rpg element to grind mobs for money or items to upgrade or buy better and stronger items.Combat is fun but takes a little getting use to if playing on hard difficulty. It can get a bit addicting in some cases. Especially if lining up combos of over 200. Take note no you are not killing 200 enemies. You are chaining attacks together on 1-6 enemies and possible moving onto the next group while keeping that chain. Depending on you attack damage you can chain bosses very high. Some areas you can run into up to maybe 20+ enemies but that is if you just run past everything and let it follow you.Voice acting is done really well also. Some will say it’s nothing special, but I’ve heard plenty of voice acting in full games that just don't compete with this game. It has a neat art workReplay ability is a little bit of a different story. There is not a lot that will change if you play and start a new game. Only one quest in the game can be changed, depending what choice you choose. Other than that, everything else will play out the same. Not that hard to get all the achievements if you’re looking to get 100% in the game. You could power run though the game in a few hours if you desired, but I took me time and explored and hunted down everything in the game. It took me around 18 hours to complete cause of that. The game is also easy to pick up and stop within minutes of starting the game with save points never being too far away.Difficulty can range from very easy to very hard. Should you wish to play it for just the story but still enjoy the combat, you can set it to easy. This will allow you to die as many time as you wish without hurting your characters progress, story, are the combat you are in. Only drawback is you lose your current chain. Personally you need to set it to hard to even get a challenge out of it. This will make death permanent and you will be sent back to your last save unless you have a revivable stone. Which should you need to you can buy them from shops which have unlimited amounts. You can see all the time the developer took into making this game with the amount of settings and design that went into the game. This game was mostly done by one person over the course of 4 years.  He needs a pat on the back for making such a good game. Really this is how good games should be. Over all this is a great game. And well worth the time and small investment depending if you buy it at full or on sale on steam. In the end you will definitely be tipping your hat to the author.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2016
												This game has a terrible story, is full of used tropes, has a very basic combat system and no meaningful progression system - besides a Metroidvania set of abilities which allow you to progress, but barely alter gameplay.Yet it is absolutely amazing.The story doesn't matter, because what matters is the moment, what matters is the colourful characters and their compelling dialogues and unusual, yet on-point delivery. Yes when you look back on it, that story was bad - but did you reall care while playing?The tropes don't matter, because they are used well. I'll indulge myself in a stupid fetch quest for an ungrateful character if it allows me to screw him over.The basic combat system doesn't matter, because the floatiness of it all is exploited and becomes a game mechanics. I'd bet you were not supposed to do half the moves you can accomplish in this game. But they are incredibly satisfying to pull off regardless.The absence of progression system does not matter, because you will learn by playing that the tools at your disposal from the start can actually accomplish much more than you first thought. You learn by playing, in the moment.There are a LOT of things in this game that when considered on their own are completely unimpressive. But Dust:An Elysian Tale is the epitome of "greater than the sum of its parts". Everything just fits and works together. I never once looked back and say "uh that wasn't actually that great now that I think about" because I didn't need to. I was too busy enjoying fast-paced combos over a brilliant soundtrack, in a vivid magical world populated by weird species.If only the final chapter didn't completely crumble, this would have possibly been the absolute best experience I ever had. But as it stands now, it was just amazing.

												I really enjoyed playing through this game. It looks beautiful – the backgrounds and characters all look good and move really well, the attack effects look sweet and all together it is amazing.I laughed pretty hard at a few points, most of them related to Fidget, but also Matti and a couple of the other characters. Genuinely sad moments too. The level design is varied and interesting, and it never felt like a chore going back to the newly accessible areas with new unlocked abilities. The mini-map is also well designed for showing where things can still be found with searching for almost everything. Whenever I had problems getting past something there was never that old school frustration with the game, but with myself. The difficulty is pretty easy on normal mode, and I’m planning to take a shot on finishing it in tough mode now to see if the challenge improves. The full on duststorm spam attacks were very fun for the first play through, too! Well spaced save points, often entertaining voice acting (Fidget was cool!) and it isn’t like this is the first game I played with a two legged talking animal as the main character (that might well have been Master System Castle of Illusion). Bought it in a Steam sale, but the full price isn't too high and probably worth it!

content:
ry 28, 2016
												Dust is a 2-D hack & slash action platformer with RPG elements and branching paths, similar to the Castlevania series.  Unlike those games, however, Dust eschews heavy exploration and technical battles in favor of lightning-fast mobility and hordes of enemies that will often have the player racking up combos of several hundred hits as they leap from target to target seamlessly without ever touching the ground.APPROXIMATE LENGTH10 hours for the main story, plus another 10 for all the sidequests & secretsPROS(+) The combat system is magnificent both mechanically and visually: easy to learn, fun to use, and amazing to watch(+) Beautiful visual style in both backgrounds and sprites(+) Music is fully orchestrated and blends well with the settings(+) Complete voice acting for all dialog, with high quality performances all around(+) Fidget is adorable and hilariousCONS(-) Plot & dialog can get pretty melodramatic(-) Items & crafting system is little more than a forced burden(-) Animated cutscenes are of mediocre quality and feel out of place(-) Difficulty curve starts very steep, then overabundant healing items make the game too easyYOUR MILEAGE MAY VARY(?) All characters are anthropomorphic “furries”.  Some people like that.  Others don’t.OVERALLDust is a game that is just plain fun to play and experience, and feels very professionally made.  Has some issues, but overall delivers on what it sets out to do.

content:
er 3, 2013
												Holy wow. Look at this artwork. I originally bought the game just because it was so amazingly pretty, and started playing it with the thought that the story would be terrible and the voice acting mediocre. Boy, was I wrong. The story is so compelling that it drew me in, even when I wasn't even planning to let myself be drawn in by it. And for indie voice actors/actresses, these people have done a stellar job. As far as combat is concerned, this combat is amazingly satisfying. I'm not terribly into hack-and-slashes, but this one does a stellar job of making you feel like a powerful warrior by giving you lots of intuitive combos and such. And if you're like me and you just want to mash one or two buttons, there's a lot of different combos with just the left and right mouse buttons, which really makes you want to stop mashing buttons and think about what you're doing instead. It works beautifully.It's hard to believe that this is a console port, but it is, and the port was done so amazingly well that it's far better than most native PC games I've played.Of course, the question of furries always comes up with anthropomorphic animals (Like those that appear in this game). From what little I've seen, furry art tends to be... well, furry. The characters here are clean-cut and undersexualized in comparison, and really look more like Looney Tunes than anything else. I'll be honest; I'm not into anthro stuff at all, but these characters are drawn well enough that I don't mind. And what 90's kid grew up without Looney Tunes? Well, a few, obviously, but the rest of us didn't care at the time about anthro-looking characters, so why care now?Anyway, overall this game is stellar, and I'm mighty impressed with the cool stuff this guy did with a seemingly simple engine. Did I mention this game was made by one guy? This game was made by one guy. And you can feel the love he poured into every pore. And hey, if nothing else, go into this game to wander around and admire the scenery. It's beautiful.

												I highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of "Metroidvania" style exploration-based action adventure games. This game is most reminiscent to me of Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia in how the game is split up into multiple explorable areas linked together by a world map (as opposed to it being just one huge map like many of this style of game have). Also, as with this style of game, backtracking is a must as there will always be some section of the map or hidden chest that you just can't reach without one of the additional abilities you'll learn throughout the game. But they do make it easy to figure out where you need to return to thanks to a helpful map system.Fluid animation, great art style and voice acting, and an engaging narrative also give this game a high recommendation from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Strikes a perfect balance between providing the backtracking and exploration the Metroidvania genre is known for and maintaing a constant sense of knowing what you need to do. Recommended to anyone with even a passing interest in the genre. Pros:-Fantastic visual design-Great writing-Clear, yet interesting level and quest design-Tons of secrets and optional quests, many of which aren't completable when you first get to them-Impressive enemy variety prevents using the same combat tactics for too long-Voice acting for the main cast is very well doneCons:-Several minor characters are poorly acted. They're not awful, but there's a noticeable drop in quality between them and Dust/Fidget in conversation.-Although the way you approach combat has to change throughout the game, mashing left click is generally all you need from the combo system, at least on Normal. Other:-It took me about 9 hours to finish Normal with around 70% completing. Going for 100% would probably take another 4 hours, and I'd expect higher difficulties to add to that significantly. -Some of Fidget's abilities can utterly destroy the balance of the game if you go all out for them. This may not be true on higher difficulties, and it's your choice to use them in combat regardless. -I was disappointed that only one quest had a branching ending and that, (MINOR SPOILERS) (EXTRA WARNING SPACE) although the villain's dialogue is written in a tone that implied he wasn't totally evil, his actions are never justified as anything other than genocide. (END SPOILERS) I don't consider either of these a con since it's expected from this genre, but it is missed potential.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 18
												This game is superb. If you are looking for a great indie 2D action platformer, this is a game to get. The game mixes level-by-level gameplay of older side scrolling games with secret hunting and exploration of a metroidvania.  Fuse that with a combo system that actively rewards the player with bonus XP for playing skillfully and you have one amazingly fun action-platform-metroidvania-brawler-whatever-it-is-but-who-cares-it's-great. The first thing that will hit you is the amazing hand-drawn art and animations. This is an absolutely beautiful game to behold. The voice acting is a bit spotty at times but overall, well executed. The bomb sprout puzzles are a bit tedious but so satisfying when you solve them, bosses were way too easy but still fun none the less, some of the diolague can be excized as it outright tells you a puzzle solution, but it doesn't handhold so often that it becomes patronizing, and the ester eggs are just adorable. I haven't found half of the secrets this game holds, so there's still a lot of stuff left for me to do. But, I did complete the story; I will not spoil the ending but I will say it is an ending that leaves lots of mixed emotions, but in a good way. TL;DR the game isn't perfect, but no game is. This is the most fun I had in a 2D game since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. Some nitpicks here and there but those could be attributed to the fact that the development team was one person, and a multi-man team could have made more mistakes than fixed them. Overall, this game is a 9/10, one of my favorites, and it definately deserves the overwhelmingly positive reception it gets.

content:
er 27, 2013
												Easily one of my favorite Indie games out there. Dust: An Elysian Tail fancies a story about a protagonist's lost memories as he moves forward to uncover them. The game features a well written story, brilliant music, and some pretty decent graphics to boot. The voice acting is also something worth commending too...as each NPC has its own unique voice and personality.The game is a side-scroll RPG and while that may sound strange at first - it's actually well done. My only "complaint" is that a sequel hasn't been officially announced yet. XDIf you're on the fence about purchasing this game - go for it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
26, 2016
												This is probably one of the best games I have ever impulsed buyed from a Steam Market.Characters are engaging and have wonderful designs. The voice Actors truly feel like they loved working on this game. Level design can be a little difficult to work with, but you will never feel like the game is being unfair. With plenty of side paths to explore, you will eventually find that this game doesn't expect you to 100% this game. In fact, it goes past 122% with all of the secrets you are capable of finding. From hidden "characters", keys, map exploration and Time Trial areas to complete, you will always have something to do.On top of this, the combat is very fluid. It is clearly designed to be super flashy and strange, but I truly love this aspect. The combat itself is incredibly easy to learn and moderately difficult to master. As a result, you will never feel like you got hurt due to gameplay issues, but you will quickly lose track of your position if you just spam the keys.So I highly recommend this game, especially if it is on sale. I truly believe the game is worth the full amount, however this is a one-time playthrough type of game. You will enjoy the experience to no end, but it lacks in replayability. For anyone that wishes to see gameplay before buying, I recommend viewing my videos below:Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLJZtGKFNc15a2pjs2CdvKzJ2vRgP4UnNtSteam Videos: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198041976310/videos/

content:
y 13, 2014
												Now before i begin my review, i have to say something first:If it weren't for an animated SFM video about Fidget, and my curiosity about why Fidget is so adorable, i never would've discovered this game. I'm so glad i did, though.Now the actual review:This game is what first looks like a MetroidVania, beat-em up, adventure game. But it's way more than that. The entire game is pure epic. The gameplay is intense and fun, the story is eventful and heart-pounding, the cast of characters are ALL lovable (I <3 Fidget), and the music is outstanding!The biggest thing i love about this game though, is especially the story and the characters. All of the characters have unique personality (Dust is cool, Fidget is childishly cute, Ahrah is the serious one of the main trio, and even the each NPCs have unique personalities) The dialogues in the game are hilarious, and have many memorable and quotable moments. It feels like watching a movie (spoilers,  There are some anime-like cutscenes, following the original 'Elysian Tail' movie style. Both the movie and this game is the same creator  )I love this game, i love the people behind it (one person doing the sole programming and graphics for over 4 years of development, plus music composer group, and voice actors)I only wish the game had some sorta replay value (besides replaying the game in a higher difficulty), but overall, this game was a wonderful experience.Get this game, it's awesome, i demand it!EDIT: Now nominated for a Steam Award!

content:
ry 18
												This game is superb. If you are looking for a great indie 2D action platformer, this is a game to get. The game mixes level-by-level gameplay of older side scrolling games with secret hunting and exploration of a metroidvania.  Fuse that with a combo system that actively rewards the player with bonus XP for playing skillfully and you have one amazingly fun action-platform-metroidvania-brawler-whatever-it-is-but-who-cares-it's-great. The first thing that will hit you is the amazing hand-drawn art and animations. This is an absolutely beautiful game to behold. The voice acting is a bit spotty at times but overall, well executed. The bomb sprout puzzles are a bit tedious but so satisfying when you solve them, bosses were way too easy but still fun none the less, some of the diolague can be excized as it outright tells you a puzzle solution, but it doesn't handhold so often that it becomes patronizing, and the ester eggs are just adorable. I haven't found half of the secrets this game holds, so there's still a lot of stuff left for me to do. But, I did complete the story; I will not spoil the ending but I will say it is an ending that leaves lots of mixed emotions, but in a good way. TL;DR the game isn't perfect, but no game is. This is the most fun I had in a 2D game since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. Some nitpicks here and there but those could be attributed to the fact that the development team was one person, and a multi-man team could have made more mistakes than fixed them. Overall, this game is a 9/10, one of my favorites, and it definately deserves the overwhelmingly positive reception it gets.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
28, 2014
												Have no fear, this game is completly abstinent! But I think that's to be expected from a game rated E 10+!Dust is an action, platforming, RPG. The sole mechanic is the "Dust Storm", a special move that lets you glide through the air and attack enemies. This move assists in combat as well as platforming.The game's level design is split up so that you are platforming half the time, and the other half you are mowing down bad guys. It is unfortunate that there are only two distinct moments when you are doing both at the same time, and I would have appreciated more moments that combined combat and platforming.Many areas are blocked off at the beginning of the game until you unlock the special ability that lets bypass the specific obstacle blocking your way. These blocked off areas don't conceal anything super special, but I find a lot of joy exploring the map trying to find all the hidden chests.The story is well written and well executed, and kept me engaged the entire time. There were certain sad moments that didn't effect me that much, but the chills I got at the cutscene before the final boss made up for that! There were countless jokes thrown in along the way that made me laugh!Overall, I think the game was a pleasent expierence and I would strongly recommend it!

content:
2, 2014
												I am generally not a fan of 2d platformers; I got more than enough of them during the 8 and 16bit eras.  However there are some exceptions that are so well made that I can't help but love them.  This is one of those exceptions.  From the endearing cartoonish art style and decent idle animations to the *truly* excellent sound and music design and decent voice acting (especially for an indie game!) to the well crafted gameplay, this is a top example of the genre and worth a playthrough by anyone, period.  Take it from a critic of the genre, this is a new standard bearer for which other 2d platformers should be judged by.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Dust is a very well balanced mix of metroid and castlevania with a brawler-like combat system and rpg elements. The story is well implemented, and supported by a great soundtrack, beautiful art and fun gameplay. The game mechanics are solid with a great leveling system, that rewards high combos in a intreresting way and fine-tuned controls. Usually when a game delivers a solid story it lacks good gameplay, but here I was intrigued the whole way through. But Dust delivers on both ends. It also encouraged exploring the levels using the abilities you learn throughout the game in very clever ways. It's difficult to find anything to complain about. Dust does everything it needs to do right and more. One of the best games I've played in recent history and I would recommend it to anybody who enjoys gameplay from brawlers or metrodvania games, or even someone who just enjoys aesthetics and story. 9/10

content:
0, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a wonderful experience of a Side Scrolling Hack N' Slash game, and I'm here to tell you why.The game starts off with you playing as Dust, a... furry (?) who woke up in the middle of the forests who dealt with amnesia, and is awfully confused on whom he is, and is confronted by Fidget the Nimbat, and Ahrah the Sword. You set out on a perilious journey to discover Dust's past and face all kinds of wicked monsters across the world.The game features extremely satisfying and smooth combat despite it being limited to 2D, yet, it plays so well.The game's combo system works by pressing two buttons, one for slashing, and another for extra combos. You gain new abilities, most likely to help you in enemy confrontrations when you play more of the game.The game world is absolutely lovely and beautiful to look at, as well as the scenery you come across. It is quite expansive, as you head out to new areas to explore the world.The combat can sometimes get repetitive and tiring after a while, as the fight mechanics do not change, but the game can make up for this with it's wonderful speed and fluent style of gameplay, that happens so quickly. It is very awesome.The difficulty is not in any way lacking, unless if you have mastered the combat to the extreme, as it allows you to pick which difficulty you would prefer, easy, moderate, or hard.Sent on:3:02 pmThere are many characters and side quests to tackle on if you do not want to try and finish the main game's storyline, as they give you time to explore the world for secrets, treasures, and quests to start on your own time.It features a nice quick leveling up system, that once you've gained enough experience points, you can choose a stat you'd like to improve, as it keeps the game extremely fresh and impressive.The game allows you to craft new items to your liking that has stats you'd generally prefer to have and use, such as armor, sword buffs, pendents, rings, etc.Dust An Elysian Tail may seem short to some who've played and decided to go on a quick speed-through, but it is a fun experience nevertheless and I suggest buying at full price to support the developer 100%, since a lot of love andeffort to making this game. Kudos.HOPING SEQUEL COMES OUT IN THE FUTURE! MUAAAAAAH!

content:
y 13, 2014
												Now before i begin my review, i have to say something first:If it weren't for an animated SFM video about Fidget, and my curiosity about why Fidget is so adorable, i never would've discovered this game. I'm so glad i did, though.Now the actual review:This game is what first looks like a MetroidVania, beat-em up, adventure game. But it's way more than that. The entire game is pure epic. The gameplay is intense and fun, the story is eventful and heart-pounding, the cast of characters are ALL lovable (I <3 Fidget), and the music is outstanding!The biggest thing i love about this game though, is especially the story and the characters. All of the characters have unique personality (Dust is cool, Fidget is childishly cute, Ahrah is the serious one of the main trio, and even the each NPCs have unique personalities) The dialogues in the game are hilarious, and have many memorable and quotable moments. It feels like watching a movie (spoilers,  There are some anime-like cutscenes, following the original 'Elysian Tail' movie style. Both the movie and this game is the same creator  )I love this game, i love the people behind it (one person doing the sole programming and graphics for over 4 years of development, plus music composer group, and voice actors)I only wish the game had some sorta replay value (besides replaying the game in a higher difficulty), but overall, this game was a wonderful experience.Get this game, it's awesome, i demand it!EDIT: Now nominated for a Steam Award!
