number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 15, 2016
												First and Foremost, while there are a large amount of support staff, this game is largely the result one man's work.  Dean Dodrill did a phenominal job bringing this to life and while I'm usually not willing to give leniance to games simply because of they have a smaller dev team, I feel this game is worthy of an exception.The game is quite pretty and you can tell that Dean's first love is animation.  There is beautiful detail in a lot of the work and the environments ooze character and personality.  It's the kind of art direction that a larger studio would never really get 'right' because Dust's art is the result of a singular vision, not designed by a committee.  While the artistic front is not as polished and as jaw-dropping as say, Ori and the Blind Forest, it's definitely a strong point and again, for a single person who kinda just wanted to do animation, it's nothing short of fantastic.The combat is fluid, fair, and manages to feel pretty good.  The mechanics follow a lot of the standards that are expected in a action-combat game.  While the game feels pretty good to play, it lacks depth and has a lot of contextual actions that trade fine control for ease of combat.I bought this game because I wanted to find a 2D Devil May Cry and I learned a something playing through Dust:  DMC is hard to make.A game like DMC4 has systems are ultra tight and provide a platform for the player to do amazing things if you invest the time to learn them.  It has a skill ceiling that might as well be infinite due to the shear number of options you have as a player, and as difficulty ramps up, the game will expect you to use those options with a kind of fluency that takes hours and hours to master.  Dust does not have that kind of depth.  A lot of the combat systems aren't perfect.  Attacks in the air kind of auto-target anything close by, sacrificing player control at times when you'd rather not.  You can lock almost every enemy into an infinite loop of uninterruptable damage in a couple different ways, none of which are terribly difficult to perform.  Bosses have pretty predictable patterns that are easy to abuse and instead of fighting a dynamic fight that requires action and reaction, you are kinda stuck just doing 'the thing that works'.There are a few other problems with the systems in place.  Attacks that would kill you will leave you at 1 HP as long as you have at least 50% of the HP the attack would do.  This means, that healing past that threshold is a mistake, and that max HP is effectively worthless.  You get bonus XP based on your combo, but you can farm combo with your secondary attack from your friendly NPC and since combo isn't damage, but rather hit count, it is in your best interest to keep her damage as low as possible while you just spam a screenwide AoE, allowing you to easily push your combo to several hundred with just a handful of monsters on the screen, which translates to easy levels.  There are a lot of counterintuitive systems that are ripe for abuse.I was kinda hoping for a game with as tight of design as a modern DMC and I didn't really get that, but regardless, the game is a fine entry in it's own right.  Despite their flaws, the mechanics aren't frustrating and as long as you go into the game with the right expectations, You'll find an enjoyable experience.

content:
1, 2016
												Alright-y. I have just finished the game with roughly 14 hours worth of playtime, and oh boy what a game. I loved it. The world was deep and rich with lore, all the characters were well rounded with ample story to give them plenty of life. The main character is well thought out in terms of his purpose and what makes him special. The game can be rather changing and isn't afraid to bite you in the ♥♥♥♥ if you aren't ready for it. And the in game secret challenges were well thought out and hard. For a long time I struggled with healing items making it a real challenge fighting all the enemies (specially the bigger ones).  Sometimes I struggled with the direction I had to go and I think that might just be because I was thick. The backdrops and scenery are GORGEOUS they are made so well and there is one in particular that was very eye catching (Giant ♥♥♥ statues).The bosses were amazing, and really challenging, especially the last boss he was a real challenge and I found it very fun to verse him even though I had to burn through all my healing items (even on normal holy ♥♥♥♥). However it would have been nice if as I was fighting him the health bar didn't completely refill after every little story moment, it would have been far better to make one health bar and have it drain far slower then in the X number of times you have to fight him after a story moment (I wont tell you how many), both was though do tell you roughly how long the fight is going to go, my way leaves it less a mystery however. I thoroughly enjoyed the music and ambient noises (save for the mansions after you had to do a little running) and the voice acting was top quality though 2 or 3 voices had gotten a little grating at times.Overall it is a great game and I highly recommend it if you love side scrolling fighting games. The mechanics are just right for the game and the way it introduces it to you is just right, just watch out all that clicking may warrant a new mouse (Or J, K and L Keys). The music is perfect and the lore is able to pull you in and keep you interested in the world you are fighting for.9.6/10P.S. I have more hours then this. I just don't have a constant internet connection.

content:
9, 2013
												It always makes me wonder why a game like this gets almost totally ignored by most mainstream players. Why? Is it because of the art style? Or the fact that it doesn't cost $120?Its a fairly smooth and enjoyable beat-em up with some platforming, RPG and questing elements which all mix in very well with one another. You typically won't get bored with the opponents and encounters due to their diversity and the art style is really well done - I'd love it if a certain universe of mine had even half the graphical quality this game has.It is a bit short, clocking in at around 7 to 8 hours but it really depends on the difficulty. If you play this, play on normal or higher - normal itself could be considered "easy" where easy could be considered "toddler" difficulty.It really doesn't have any flaws, it even controls well with the mouse and keyboard - argurably one of the smoothest controls I've ever used in a game like this. And, you will like the writing for the game, whoever wrote for Fidget needs to write for more games.9\10. No Multiplayer and lack of replay appeal if you beat the game on the hardest difficulty, and if you know me, I don't give high scores lightly - especially on these sorts of games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2014
												As far as I know, there's only one word that can aptly sum up Dust: An Enlysian Tail - and that's "phenomenal". There's a reason that a small, somewhat niche game can sell over a million copies and it's simply because it's that good.Let's start at the beginning, and that means story. If a little convoluted at times - which can to an extent serve as a point in the writer's favour - the story is mostly simple, without being patronizing or slow. Players are given tiem to go at their own pace, but always met with a warm welcome when they do decide to push ever onward. Obviously avoiding spoilers, I'll tell anyone that this game has a story to rival almost any AAA game out there.The next point I want to make is the combat, because I can't go very long without talking about Dust's combat, because it's better than any other scroller/fighter I've ever played, and that's quite a few. The problem with fighters like this is often response times or getting locked into an animation, making for slow or frustrating combat when you can't react to things as they happen. Dust eliminates that, as the combat is smoothe and I can personally say I never felt like my reactions were being hindered. Another good point is the simplicity (yet again, far from patronizing) of the combat. Again I'll say that personally I've never seen combat done quite as well as Dust, so I'll give you the best example. In most fighting games, I'm reduced to button-mashing. Boo me all you want, it gets results. In Dust however, I knew my combos and I knew the 4-5 buttons I needed to pull off the exact string of moves I would need in whatever situation I was handed. This stems from simplistic controls and memorable keybindings.One point I don't particularly enjoy talking about is graphics, since I tend to see a reliance on graphics as superficial, but I'll talk about them here. Of course, it's more art than graphics; all hand-drawn by a single animator, Dust is stunningly beautiful. Not only is it brilliantly drawn, the art matches the tone of the game perfectly; light, bouncy and adventurous. There were times I just had to stop and admire it, and very few games will do that to me. Literally stunning.I think that's all I had to say about Dust so tl;dr, Dust is amazing and I highly recommend you find yourself a copy.

y 2, 2014
												In short (and the game itself is short), this is a beautiful game. If you have a few hours to spare, you should give it a go. The visuals and music are both stunning, and I may even buy the soundtrack some time soon. The controls are pretty smooth (although pinpoint platforming sometimes gets a little troublesome), and while there are not that many combos to pull off, the battles are still fun and they make you look amazing as you pull off hundreds of chains and fly across the screen whilst tearing apart enemies. The characters and voice acting may be a bit cheesy, but I think it fits the overall style of the game and I found myself liking the interactions between them (primarily the two main characters). There are several side quests and challenge areas to do, so the possibility to deviate from the main storyline is there, if you like those kinds of things. I liked the number of side quests because it was not an overwhelming amount that caused me to lose sight of the main progression. If you're looking for a visually and audibly stunning hack-and-slash side-scroller, you should definitely try this game out!

1, 2014
												To start of, the art-style and art-design are extremely beautiful, giving a lot of life to the game. The characters are also very likeable, well written and have good voice-acting. The plot of the game while well written doesn't really do anything too new but the world itself is so deep that it's still very easy to get sucked into the world. You can't talk about this game without mentioning the music. It's extremely well composed and memorable. I'd even say it's worth picking up the soundtrack so you can listen to it whenever you want.As for the gameplay, it's basically a metroidvania, with a lot of the mechanics you would expect from such a game. Something it doesn't have is multiple types weapons but instead a lot of effort was put into the combat to make it more enjoyable. While you don't have that many combos you can perform, you can easily go from one to the next, making the combat really fluent.The only real negative I have is that the ending didn't give a real closure to the characters and ending a game on a low note isn't something you want since that's what the player will remember the most. Still, there's too much to experience from this game for the ending to bring it down.

content:
4, 2014
												Moderately fun side scrolling hack and slash plat forming RPG game. Played on the second hardest difficulty with a usb playstation controller and it took about 10 hours to beat it just doing the main quest line. About 2 hours of that was just grinding because I didn’t bother with the crafting system so my gear wasn’t that good. The enemies are not that difficult until you get to the last area. The greatest challenge came from the platforming as jumps were often very difficult to make. Your regular jump often does not reach high enough so you have to attack in mid air to get that extra height boost, but this makes sticking your landing in the right spot more difficult. You also often just randomly fall through platforms when you land on them which can be frustrating. I also had to restart the game on several occasions because I would just randomly fall through and get stuck inside of walls. The good thing is there are a lot of save points so even if you get stuck you don't have to restart that far back. The story line/dialog is kind of cringey, but I just skipped most of it. The environment looks pretty nice, but sometimes it is hard to tell what you can jump on or what hurts you as the background and foreground kind of blend in with the main area at times. I wouldn’t recommend buying this game at full price, but since it was included in the humble bundle 11 you can probably get it for cheap.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an action side-scrolling platformer game with a very fluid combo system and well animated attacks, giving the player a sense of simply being awesome in combat. I've played a lot of games, but nothing is quite as unique as Dust. The game gives the player the ability to move freely throughout the world, going to whichever areas they so desire to rack-up XP, explore or find hidden secrets in past levels. The story in Dust is one surrounded by mystery, the protagonist, Dust, starts off with amnesia and cannot recollect a damn thing about his past, which I know is very cliche but it suits Dust's story just fine. The protagonist is alway accompanied by a cat-ferret-bat creature by the name of Fidget (who is also the cutest damn thing I've seen since Tali in Mass Effect), who offers humorous dialogue and grants the player a ranged attack. To clarify: I f*cking love Fidget.Dust's combat system flows beautifully, utilizing a mere three buttons for attacks, the combat is simple but at the same time awe inspiring, easy to pick up on and very well made, when the player whipes out his/her first batch of enemies you immediately feel like an incredible badass and leaves you itching for more. As the game proceeds you acquire new abilities that complement your already formidible attack options and keep the game from getting stale, all the while maintaining a steady difficulty curve alongside an easy to understand XP and level-up system.Graphics-wise: It's an indy game, you don't come into it expecting mind-blowing graphics. Dust uses a simple but lovable anthropomorphic cartoon art-style that is both charming and outright adorable, but also dark and serious when it needs to be. All perfected with an amazing musical score and top quality voice acting. As well, Dust makes numerous quips at the expense of the fourth wall and makes references to other games, like Resident Evil 4 and Castlevania. The one flaw I've seen thus far is a somewhat finicky platform system. Sometimes if you don't land on a platform at exactly the right angle you're going through, which in a platformer game is a real kick to the groin.In conclusion: Dust: An Elysian Tail is fun, fluid, and highly addictive. I definitely recommend anyone reading this to pick it up immediately.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 26, 2014
												One caveat before I begin my review: I got this game for roughly $4 through the Humble Store, so some of my opinion is emotionally affected by the price point. Now, onto the rest of the review!I've played a lot of 2D side-scrolling action games with RPG elements at this point, but "Dust: An Elysian Tail" stands out at first because of the game's impressive artwork. The backgrounds are splendidly rendered, and the character design is neat and well done. In short, Dust is a very pretty game, and it rates well on eye-candy alone. However, what sucked me in the most about this game is its fun, simplistic combat system. Whether you're a vicious button masher (like myself) or a combo-obsessive technician, you can get hours of entertainment out of this game as you wage your war against evil. I found that this game was easy to binge despite its simplicity. So, we've got a visually pretty game with a fun little combat system, right? Well, in terms of criticism, I can only really levy any on a single element: the story. The story itself, where you play as the mysterious warrior protagonist Dust, is a pretty straightforward affair. You attempt, with the help of the mystical Blade of Ahrah and its dimunitive guardian Fidget, to recover Dust's identity while helping to defeat an evil that has plagued the land of Falana for years. The dialogue and banter between Dust and Fidget can be kind of fun at times, but the dialogue in general can be very wooden at times, especially during the game's climatic ending. The story is simple (To be fair, this was a game built for the XBox Live Arcade) but, while easy to follow, it definitely leaves you wanting a little more in a bad way. While the game touches on Christian and Taoist themes (Shout out to my friend Olse for pointing this out to me initially), it definitely comes off a little more ham-handed than one might expect. The voice acting is roughly above-average, as it shines in some areas (particularly some of the banter between Dust and Fidget), while sagging in others. All in all, for spending $4, DAET was a fantastically fun Action-RPG romp with gorgeous visuals. Its standard price is a little steep in terms of game length and replayability, but not so much that I wont recommend it. This is a game that I really suggest you buy and try. (As an additional note, I gather than Humble Hearts, the game's developer, is a one man operation. If you take my recommendation and purchase it, know that you might be enabling another game like this!)

content:
er 9, 2014
												So this was a case of needing something to occupy myself with while my wife worked on her second and third playthroughs of Dragon Age: Inquisition, so I went through my Steam library looking for something I hadn't tried yet. After seeing that Dust was an RPG metroidvania I decided to give it a try.After playing this I'm realizing I have a fondness for metroidvanias; while Guacamelee is the golden standard against which I will judge them all (that and Symphony of the Night, of course) it turns out Dust was pretty decent. The art style was pretty, though why all of the characters were anthropomorphized animals (aka furries) is beyond me. It didn't really help or hurt the game, but it did take me out of it a little. Why do some of them wear clothes, but your sidekick doesn't?Speaking of your sidekick, Fidget, ohmygoodness is her voice annoying. The game is well acted, but getting past Fidget's voice is a challenge. That said the dialog is surprisingly funny. Fidget does work as decent comic relief, "Why does it have knives for hands?! KNIVES FOR HANDS!" The overall plot is meh (evil general with ambiguous motives is trying to kill off the natives - I mean Moonbloods) though I liked the section where you are helping people in Mudpot. I found those characters way more interesting.Gameplay is solid. Standard unlock-powers-to-access-new-areas stuff (though, again, nowhere near as awesome as Guacamelee). There's also RPG stuff such as leveling up and managing gear. You can find recipes and make your own gear out of stuff you pick up from bad guys. There's a nice mechanic where if you sell an ingredient to the shopkeeper then the shop will periodically restock that ingredient, so later when you find a recipe that needs it you don't have to go grind a mob.The game's difficulty was all over the board. Sometimes I would feel like I was burning through all of my healing items and revival crystals (generally when I pushed forward in the main questline without doing side missions/looking for all the hidden treasure chests) yet by the end I had zero trouble with the final boss. Seriously, he was a chump. Also not interesting. If you're going to have me empty a boss' health meter 4 times at least have him change forms or vary his attack pattern. Not that it mattered because, as I said, he was a chump. I didn't need to bother studying the attack pattern.This game was a pleasant distraction for roughly 10 hours (didn't collect EVERY item, but did get most) and was well worth my time (especially considering I don't even remember buying it). That said, if you're looking for a metroidvania and you HAVEN'T played Guacamelee then, obviously, play that instead. If you're a fan of the genre then this is probably worth your time.

content:
er 7, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a truly special game.Done in the style of hand-drawn animation, while playing it I couldn't help feeling like I was back in my living room watching the Saturday morning caroons of my youth.  I did experience some display issues (flickering on the screen) but if you're like me, a child of the 80's,  and you experience it, I recommend pretending that you're just watching a well-worn VHS tape.  For me, that just added to the experience and even made it all the more endearing.The story is compelling and you'll likely get sucked in and want to play this exclusively until you get through it.  There are some fun Easter Eggs that you can unlock as you go along as well.  Additionally, the progression is nicely paced between leveling up and the gear that becomes available throughout - I never felt like Neo until the very end despite rarely feeling like I was in danger of dying.I chose not to 100% this game becuase I wanted to save myself some aggravation.  The collectables can be quite challenging to get (or even to find) but there is a wealth of information out there online should you choose to go that route.Between the nostalgic feel and comfortable gameplay, I would recommend this game to anyone.

y 19, 2015
												I highly recommend this game.  What first got my attention for this game was the artwork.  And it is beautiful.  But then I found it's a 2D 'platformer' game, which I'm not that big on.  However I did enjoy Castlevania and some other reviews here likened it to that game too.  Then I learned that it was almost entirely done by a single person - animation, programming, everything, other than voices and music.  So then I was very impressed.  Especially with all the other very positive reviews.  So with it being on sale I went ahead and picked it up.And 70-some hours later I'm extreamly glad I did.  I still love the artwork, but have also fallen in love with the characters and the story.  Very enjoyable voicing.  I totally love Fidget (the Nimbat that looks to be a cross of a bat and fox).  There is a very serious and interesting story told, but also lots of fun and humor mixed in.  The fighting which you do a lot of was just fine for me.  Enough challenge to be fun and worthwhile, but not to the point of frustraition.  And the platforming is more exploration and puzzling than having to make pixel-perfect jumps, for which I'm glad.All in all, if this game even looks a little interesting to you, by all means pick it up and have fun.  Even at full price it's not all that much, but on sale it's a no-brainer.

content:
er 5, 2014
												This game shows how you can still do some impressive stuff in two dimensions. The animations are wonderful, and there's so much fun to be had while slashing down enemies and finding loot around. The story itself is well developed and has several sidequests which make sense, and while there aren't dozens of them, they provide several hours of gameplay along with the main storyline. Graphic (and sound/music) wise this game is really well done, mostly in a way that makes it fun to watch and play through rather than for sheer beauty, but overall all of the characters and the places are well designed and stand out perfectly. If anything, sometimes the gameplay is repetitive, but that has mostly to do with the platform design rather than with the plot or the level design (imho), as the 2D nature of the game has some limits, but in the end the game makes really a lot to overcome each of its dimensional limits. For that matter, the amount and quality of both combos and movements of Dust make it fun to even just watch the character jumping in the air!In fact, while fighting you can also count on Fidget abilities, and some rings/pendants/etc greatly improve Fidget's combat skills, up to a point that lets you draw the fight style that suits you the most. RPG wise, this game allows you to craft several items but most of the crafting makes use of loot you can only find while killing enemies. That in turn makes for a solid system (as much as some backtracking) as it pushes you to play each area throughout, instead of buying most of what you need from a merchant.Overall, a really good game and especially a really good 2D platformer (with rpg elements), a good plot and a fighting system that makes for a lot of fun.

content:
er 3, 2013
												Holy wow. Look at this artwork. I originally bought the game just because it was so amazingly pretty, and started playing it with the thought that the story would be terrible and the voice acting mediocre. Boy, was I wrong. The story is so compelling that it drew me in, even when I wasn't even planning to let myself be drawn in by it. And for indie voice actors/actresses, these people have done a stellar job. As far as combat is concerned, this combat is amazingly satisfying. I'm not terribly into hack-and-slashes, but this one does a stellar job of making you feel like a powerful warrior by giving you lots of intuitive combos and such. And if you're like me and you just want to mash one or two buttons, there's a lot of different combos with just the left and right mouse buttons, which really makes you want to stop mashing buttons and think about what you're doing instead. It works beautifully.It's hard to believe that this is a console port, but it is, and the port was done so amazingly well that it's far better than most native PC games I've played.Of course, the question of furries always comes up with anthropomorphic animals (Like those that appear in this game). From what little I've seen, furry art tends to be... well, furry. The characters here are clean-cut and undersexualized in comparison, and really look more like Looney Tunes than anything else. I'll be honest; I'm not into anthro stuff at all, but these characters are drawn well enough that I don't mind. And what 90's kid grew up without Looney Tunes? Well, a few, obviously, but the rest of us didn't care at the time about anthro-looking characters, so why care now?Anyway, overall this game is stellar, and I'm mighty impressed with the cool stuff this guy did with a seemingly simple engine. Did I mention this game was made by one guy? This game was made by one guy. And you can feel the love he poured into every pore. And hey, if nothing else, go into this game to wander around and admire the scenery. It's beautiful.

												I highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of "Metroidvania" style exploration-based action adventure games. This game is most reminiscent to me of Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia in how the game is split up into multiple explorable areas linked together by a world map (as opposed to it being just one huge map like many of this style of game have). Also, as with this style of game, backtracking is a must as there will always be some section of the map or hidden chest that you just can't reach without one of the additional abilities you'll learn throughout the game. But they do make it easy to figure out where you need to return to thanks to a helpful map system.Fluid animation, great art style and voice acting, and an engaging narrative also give this game a high recommendation from me.

												Absolutely fantastic metroidvania title!!!  From the moment I started playing til the very end this game had me hooked.  Fun, fluid gameplay, gorgeous graphics, outstanding story with complete start to end voice acting!!!  I'm looking forward to a sequel if it comes.  Most definitely worth asking price without sale.  If you do grab this game on sale it's a steal.This game has everything you'd want in a metroidvania.  Bosses, powerups, level ups, crafting gear, merchants, challenge rooms, back tracking once you acquire the appropriate abilities and a fantastic story.  I can't stress that enough.  If you want an easy play through just do it on normal.  Normal is extremely easy!  If  you want more of a challenge make sure you select tough or hard core.  Recommending this game to anyone and especially those who love the Metroidvania genre.  This isn't a game you want to miss!  9.5/10.  Beautifully done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
26, 2015
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a kind of metroidvania that manages to pull it off with little to none incentive on backtracking the world on your own. The game uses that kind of interaction as a support instrument for world-building. This takes your for a journey that is somewhat linear with a few decision forks changing only the order you’ll beat a bit more that crazy thousand hits combos out of enemy minions (or more like will try to do that). That numbers though are actually ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with protagonist bearing a legendary talking sword Ahrah which makes all the job for that green amnesia-suffering anthropomorphic green rabbit. All kind of attacks granting you several digits are just tap of the button away. Mixing them in one flow can be tricky at first; but since that’s the one thing there is to figure out with this game, you’ll get better. So the digits in the counter will skyrocket like their counterparts do in Bayonetta or Devil May Cry.Along with those combos come level-ups and equipment. And this is where it gets a bit cumbersome. Craftable armor sets and pendants pile up, but all they do is add an incremental bonus to the usual set of stats (defense, attack, critical chance and the like). It’s a minor nuisance for the player with easily obtainable crafting components and a straightforward choices of what to wear next. Not bringing anything to the table in terms of variety or difficulty this adds a sublevel of complexity. Redundant coherence of game’s levels helps with establishing a world from a separate screens. Involvement in stat increase emphasizes the empowerment of mysterious protagonist. It wouldn’t be enough if that was the only thing Dust resorted to, but thankfully it isn’t.Slicing, jumping and projectile-shooting happens to take place in front of colorful backgrounds rich with details and looking like an according prop for a saturday morning cartoon. So do characters. With the looks comes an appropriate comical yet faithful and friendly side-kick. An orange flying hybrid of bat and squirrel goes by the name of Fidget and is the guardian of Ahrah. The mischievous little creature opposes the calm and secretive sword with attached gloom prophecy in game’s story pacing and does so with an added tongue-in-cheek attitude and kicking a few bricks out of the fourth wall.With the acting hero being amnesiac and all, the duet of sword and critter is the moving mechanism for the story with a good two dozens of accompanying characters. And either it’s a snatch-my-laundry quest or an actual story-advancing interaction, each voice and face adds up a bit mold pieces of the game together.It might seem like just being cute, referencing Disney animation classic, a main source for inspiration right in the title; but the game makes up for it with a good chunk of passion. It may not be as stellar as some with its cut-scenes. Sufficiently grim plot is predictable. Being essentially a one-man-project (with the occasional help of some people) Dust can’t excel at everything. And on the whole it still is bigger than a sum of its parts.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
7, 2013
												You will often find, among gamers and critics alike, diverse opinions that state the positives and negatives of various games, with things such as "the game is good" or "the game was too short" or "the controls suck."This is not the case with Dust: An Elysian Tail.  I have been a gamer my entire life, ostracized as a child in school by the very people now addicted to Call of Duties and Madden NFLs.  I have watched the evolution of gaming from the 8-and-16-bit era of Mario and Sonic, the evolution of PC gaming from text based RPGs to DragonAge and Skyrim.Of all the games I have played, from casual Runescape to the intensely cerebral Europa Universalis, from the flashy twitch gaming of Smash Brothers to the thought-out fights of Guild Wars.  "Dust: An Elysian Tail" is by far one of the most defining creations in the Gaming Industry.  What makes it more spectacular and amazing is the story of a single man hand-drawing and developing the game from scratch over years, of an indie developer given a chance on Xbox Arcade.Dead Dodrill has brought to us a game that, in collaboration with secondary writer Alex Kain, and composers Alexander Brandon and HypderDuck Soundworks, defines everything we love about gaming.  He brings us back to the core elements of a video game.I can say, without a doubt in my mind, that Dust: An Elysian Tail is, by far, the greatest representation of Video Games as an Artform.  If there ever any confusion or concern if games could be consider Art, Dead Dodrill has proved us otherwise.No amount of praise I could give would satisfy my love for this game.  For 17 years, Blizzard Entertainment's Starcraft franchise has held a special place in my heart as my favorite game of all time.  Upon completion of this artistic masterwork, I can say that this has changed.Dean Dodrill, Alexander Brandon, and everyone else that not only made this game possible, but brought it to the attention of the general public.  I thank you, and I heartily reccommend this game for anyone.

content:
2014
												This game is a 2D sidescrolling brawler, where you play Dust. Dust wakes up with amnesia and a talking sword next to him, and a strange animal that is like a squirel mixed with a bat. They go on adventure to discover what happened to Dust. A single playthrough is about 10 hours worth of gameplay, more if you want to go for the full 100% playthrough. It incorporates a castlevania style of gameplay as well, where you learn new tricks to overcome particular obstacles. There is only backtracking involved if you want to find all the secrets and hidden bonuses. The handdrawn visual style of the game is fresh and I personally liked it. The dev-team did some special effects too, but they sometimes obscured the screen a bit too much. Combat feels responsive with gamepad, but I cannot say if this also applies to keyboard. Towards the end I found the combat getting repettitive and I was getting a bit bored with the end stretch of the game. Still, I've very enjoyed playing it and as such I can recommend it.

content:
er 9, 2014
												So this was a case of needing something to occupy myself with while my wife worked on her second and third playthroughs of Dragon Age: Inquisition, so I went through my Steam library looking for something I hadn't tried yet. After seeing that Dust was an RPG metroidvania I decided to give it a try.After playing this I'm realizing I have a fondness for metroidvanias; while Guacamelee is the golden standard against which I will judge them all (that and Symphony of the Night, of course) it turns out Dust was pretty decent. The art style was pretty, though why all of the characters were anthropomorphized animals (aka furries) is beyond me. It didn't really help or hurt the game, but it did take me out of it a little. Why do some of them wear clothes, but your sidekick doesn't?Speaking of your sidekick, Fidget, ohmygoodness is her voice annoying. The game is well acted, but getting past Fidget's voice is a challenge. That said the dialog is surprisingly funny. Fidget does work as decent comic relief, "Why does it have knives for hands?! KNIVES FOR HANDS!" The overall plot is meh (evil general with ambiguous motives is trying to kill off the natives - I mean Moonbloods) though I liked the section where you are helping people in Mudpot. I found those characters way more interesting.Gameplay is solid. Standard unlock-powers-to-access-new-areas stuff (though, again, nowhere near as awesome as Guacamelee). There's also RPG stuff such as leveling up and managing gear. You can find recipes and make your own gear out of stuff you pick up from bad guys. There's a nice mechanic where if you sell an ingredient to the shopkeeper then the shop will periodically restock that ingredient, so later when you find a recipe that needs it you don't have to go grind a mob.The game's difficulty was all over the board. Sometimes I would feel like I was burning through all of my healing items and revival crystals (generally when I pushed forward in the main questline without doing side missions/looking for all the hidden treasure chests) yet by the end I had zero trouble with the final boss. Seriously, he was a chump. Also not interesting. If you're going to have me empty a boss' health meter 4 times at least have him change forms or vary his attack pattern. Not that it mattered because, as I said, he was a chump. I didn't need to bother studying the attack pattern.This game was a pleasant distraction for roughly 10 hours (didn't collect EVERY item, but did get most) and was well worth my time (especially considering I don't even remember buying it). That said, if you're looking for a metroidvania and you HAVEN'T played Guacamelee then, obviously, play that instead. If you're a fan of the genre then this is probably worth your time.

er 26, 2013
												What a fantastic experience this game was. Even on its third of four difficulties, I only felt genuinely challenged at a couple points, but that didn't stop me from enjoying it thoroughly.Aesthetically, the game is beautiful. Every area feels distinctly different, and none of it feels fake or half-baked. Characters and animations are great, and even the voice acting, for the most part, isn't bad.Storywise...I don't feel like I'm ever qualified to criticize a game's plotlines, but it felt good, solid, strong enough to carry the game.Functionally, things are spot on. Not once did I ever feel like I got screwed over by being unable to control myself precisely how I needed to. The game has a good system behind the numbers, even if the exponential stat growth does lead to being immensely overpowered in the latter parts.Plus, all the characters are anthros, and they're not badly done. It's not necessarily a furry game, but it certainly appeals to us.Buy it, play it, love it.

content:
er 28, 2013
												I highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of "Metroidvania" style exploration-based action adventure games. This game is most reminiscent to me of Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia in how the game is split up into multiple explorable areas linked together by a world map (as opposed to it being just one huge map like many of this style of game have). Also, as with this style of game, backtracking is a must as there will always be some section of the map or hidden chest that you just can't reach without one of the additional abilities you'll learn throughout the game. But they do make it easy to figure out where you need to return to thanks to a helpful map system.Fluid animation, great art style and voice acting, and an engaging narrative also give this game a high recommendation from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												To start of, the art-style and art-design are extremely beautiful, giving a lot of life to the game. The characters are also very likeable, well written and have good voice-acting. The plot of the game while well written doesn't really do anything too new but the world itself is so deep that it's still very easy to get sucked into the world. You can't talk about this game without mentioning the music. It's extremely well composed and memorable. I'd even say it's worth picking up the soundtrack so you can listen to it whenever you want.As for the gameplay, it's basically a metroidvania, with a lot of the mechanics you would expect from such a game. Something it doesn't have is multiple types weapons but instead a lot of effort was put into the combat to make it more enjoyable. While you don't have that many combos you can perform, you can easily go from one to the next, making the combat really fluent.The only real negative I have is that the ending didn't give a real closure to the characters and ending a game on a low note isn't something you want since that's what the player will remember the most. Still, there's too much to experience from this game for the ending to bring it down.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2014
												This game shows how you can still do some impressive stuff in two dimensions. The animations are wonderful, and there's so much fun to be had while slashing down enemies and finding loot around. The story itself is well developed and has several sidequests which make sense, and while there aren't dozens of them, they provide several hours of gameplay along with the main storyline. Graphic (and sound/music) wise this game is really well done, mostly in a way that makes it fun to watch and play through rather than for sheer beauty, but overall all of the characters and the places are well designed and stand out perfectly. If anything, sometimes the gameplay is repetitive, but that has mostly to do with the platform design rather than with the plot or the level design (imho), as the 2D nature of the game has some limits, but in the end the game makes really a lot to overcome each of its dimensional limits. For that matter, the amount and quality of both combos and movements of Dust make it fun to even just watch the character jumping in the air!In fact, while fighting you can also count on Fidget abilities, and some rings/pendants/etc greatly improve Fidget's combat skills, up to a point that lets you draw the fight style that suits you the most. RPG wise, this game allows you to craft several items but most of the crafting makes use of loot you can only find while killing enemies. That in turn makes for a solid system (as much as some backtracking) as it pushes you to play each area throughout, instead of buying most of what you need from a merchant.Overall, a really good game and especially a really good 2D platformer (with rpg elements), a good plot and a fighting system that makes for a lot of fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												This is a beautiful example of how to make a game when you don't have a Bethesda-class budget to play with.  The devs didn't try to go head-to-head with the latest hyper-realistic FPS or amazingly vast open world.  Instead, they took a very old, tried-and-true genre (the Metroidvania action platformer) and did it really well.The animation is smooth, and the sound is pleasant.  The storytelling allows itself some indulgent moments with overdramatic tropes, but then lightens up again with fourth-wall breaking, winking references to other games, and comedically petty sidequests for NPCs, rather than continually wallowing in melodrama.The style of gameplay is dated, and Dust can't compete on technical merits with big-studio offerings, but what makes this a pleasant experience is the degree of polish.  The devs put a lot of attention into this game, and it shows.

												I am in love with this game.  I've never completed a game so fast in my life.  Every spare time I had (since I've just finished my exams and am now on my break) was spent sitting in front of my computer playing this game.I love the artwork, as hand-drawn graphics had always appealed to me. It's nice to see a break from the usual "good guys always wins no matter what" pattern in other games.  I also love the little play on words, and of course, the sassiness in the dialogues.

												I was pretty surprised by how good this game was. The combat is fluid and dust is easy to move around, making finding secrets and defeating bosses more a matter of skill than trial and error. The food and crafting systems seemed a bit superfluous but also added a little Korean charm to the game. 												I had high expectations for this game and after starting it up at least once I could confirm and justify those terms. content:
er 28, 2013
												Gameplaywise, it's straightforward : you have one sword and learn several moves throughout the game. I thought this would limit the gameplay, making it boring at some point, but it didn't. The game is relatively short if you decide to do the campaign only, and becomes longer if you decide to do the subquest. You can find equipment to upgrade your sword & be more competitive in fights. The game itself is really easy, if you wish for a challenge, directly jump to the hardcore difficulty, where you really die easily if you gets hit (my advice : don't try to speedrun it, use combos & dodge as much as possible).Graphically : it's a cel-shaded style plat-former, who really take inspiration into Don Bluth's An American Tail animated movie in terms of artstyle (they even made the same pun). At first I thought it would be a problem since I'm really not a fan of the furry genre (due to what the Internet did to it, mostly) but it really only took inspiration in the Don Bluth movie style and never try to sexualize the characters like you can see many games do whenever they try to add androgynous animal characters. So yeah, I really felt I was watching an old animated movie, with the same kind of message Don Bluth himself would be able to convey (about war, destruction of nature, etc...)The story is cute, it's nothing great but it's very cute, very well acted, and I appreciate the voice actors' effort in the play.One big plus for this game is the music : the music is absolutely fantastic, and one of my favourite soundtrack in videogame's history. Not even kidding.It's charming, it's fun, it's pretty. The music is beautiful.It is a wonderful tail... I mean tale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 12, 2016
After beating Chapter 1 (hardcore mode) reviewSo far, so good. And I mean really good. The story, admittedly, has been done before (Ex-superevilarmy soldier suddenly can't remember things because reasons and is now good guy but slowly uncovers his dark past and has to reconcile with his sins etc etc), but it isn't presented or executed (at least so far) in an incredible cliched or dull manner. It's clear that Dust, the main protagonist and player character, actually did some pretty evil stuff and assisted in the annihilation of a race (or maybe only partially). When you figure out more about Dust, you start to become wary of learning about his past, afraid of what you might uncover and realize who you are playing as.Gameplay is solid, hack-and-slash type deal with mobs of enemies coming at you once. I immediately went to hardcore mode starting out, and personally I feel like a lot of the difficulty does come simply from damage outputs from enemies being increased. I can be dancing around everyone, sawing through flocks of those flying toad dudes with dust storm, and suddenly git rekt if I get hit like once or twice (ie the insta-kill giants, but considering they're giants that makes sense). This isn't to say the enemy AI aren't smart in their own right, definitely not a bunch of bumbling idiots with aim-bot and ridiculous stats (*cough*modernfps*cough*), but it does effect my experience enough to be noted. The combos, tho, the combos. I swear I feel like a Touhou character whizzing around and throwing everyone and everything into the air and then showering the battlefield with bullets from Fidget and making Storm from the X-Men look like a South Dakota summer breaze on a Sunday in July. I am rewarded executing a long chain of combos and moves and what nots with extra experience rather than just spamming a basic or other attack. In fact, you can't even spam a single attack or any single set of attacks, because you'll git rekt. The mechanics of each move or dust storm or Fidget's bullets force you to change things up as you go along because even these super-amazing-I'm-a-♥♥♥♥ing-god move sets have their limits, even hurting yourself in some casese if not executed properly. Skill is needed to cut through literal armies of monster mooks.Speaking of the enemies, the design is repititive but at the same time varied. In the first chapter, you'll see the same monsters from the beginning continuously re-appear throughout to the end, while others are still added as you go along. However, very rarely did I see more than two of the same looking hairless-club-wielding-dog-thing, each enemy type has several skins to change around and add some color to what would otherwise be a boring homogeneous legion. Even futher, the basic design and look of each enemy is pleasant to look at in itself. They're colorful and full of little details that give the mooks some character of their own. I even found myself feeling a little sorry for them, wondering if they had hopes and dreams of their own, but I guess that's just my traumatization from Undertale talking.The final boss of chapter one definitely threw the plot for a loop. At first I thought "oh no super cliche warlord guy rallying usually non-threatening army of mountain monsters into a full-fledged and organized assault where HAVEN'T I seen this before", which is still technically true even after defeating him and listening to his dialogue. But holy ♥♥♥♥ did I feel like a god damn prick when his backstory was revealed and suddenly things are going from happy-go-lucky fantasty monster slaying to "oh my god what am I doing I'm a monster". Something that did definitely irk me after the boss fight however was the fact that you still go about slaying the monsters, which Fidget even speaks up about wondering if they should continue slaughtering them.Voice acting is a little cringy at times, and that's nothing from the actual voices but from the lines themselves, tho I am an anti-social prick that rarely has a decent face-to-face conversation in real life so I probably wouldn't know. However I will not lie in saying anyone can tell the budget wasn't exactly sky-high when listening.The friendly characters are nice to chat with, that's for certain. No one's overly annoying or obviously a rip-off of some other character from another game to serve the same purpose. I really like the travelling merchant guy and his mysterious appearance, can't tell what sort of anthropomorphic animal he is. However I distinctly remember wanting to close off every conversation with the merchent in Aurora village as quickly as possible.Finally, a comment on the anthropomorphism. At first glance of this game I thought the only reason it had an overwhelmingly positive response was because only furries were looking at it and only praising it because anthro (which I would like to say really quickly that I don't give a rat's ♥♥♥ if you're a furry, I just call out circle-jerking when I see it). However I was slapped across the face with wrong when I realize it's more of a Disney-esque anthro thing going on, rather than just "because anthro". The designs of the characters are cartoony and simple, I can tell only just enough time was spent on them to be aesthetically pleasing and not overly elaborate with human-animal mixture stuff.That being said, I'm still carving my way through chapter 2, and will post my review for that probably maybe idk. Thanks for reading.

content:
y 3, 2015
												Let me start off by saying this indie game is beautiful. The backgrounds are a joy to behold and the music compliments it well. Weather you are in the forest, in the caves, on a snow covered mountain or whatever, the environment is always very pretty to look at.Gameplay is wild. You hack and slash and spin and bombard your enemies into submission with the grace a tornado of ninjas. There really is something magical about it. I went through the game twice and throwing an enemy 80 feet into the air, flying up at him, grabbing him, and piledriving him back into the ground never lost its appeal. If I had oto complain about the combat, I'd say it can get very easy to lose track of what's going on in the chaos and that the player could have been given more attack combinations. However, as it stands it is visceral and amusing.Additionally the game has a Metroidvania style exploration aspect to it. It has keys to find to unlock treasure chests you find, some require upgrades to reach, and it has some puzzles to it help break-up any tedium you may feel from destroying you enemies all day.In short, if you like pretty, hack-n-slash, Metroidvania games you owe it to yourself to pick up this Indie title.

content:
2014
												This game is a 2D sidescrolling brawler, where you play Dust. Dust wakes up with amnesia and a talking sword next to him, and a strange animal that is like a squirel mixed with a bat. They go on adventure to discover what happened to Dust. A single playthrough is about 10 hours worth of gameplay, more if you want to go for the full 100% playthrough. It incorporates a castlevania style of gameplay as well, where you learn new tricks to overcome particular obstacles. There is only backtracking involved if you want to find all the secrets and hidden bonuses. The handdrawn visual style of the game is fresh and I personally liked it. The dev-team did some special effects too, but they sometimes obscured the screen a bit too much. Combat feels responsive with gamepad, but I cannot say if this also applies to keyboard. Towards the end I found the combat getting repettitive and I was getting a bit bored with the end stretch of the game. Still, I've very enjoyed playing it and as such I can recommend it.

content:
y 19, 2015
												I highly recommend this game.  What first got my attention for this game was the artwork.  And it is beautiful.  But then I found it's a 2D 'platformer' game, which I'm not that big on.  However I did enjoy Castlevania and some other reviews here likened it to that game too.  Then I learned that it was almost entirely done by a single person - animation, programming, everything, other than voices and music.  So then I was very impressed.  Especially with all the other very positive reviews.  So with it being on sale I went ahead and picked it up.And 70-some hours later I'm extreamly glad I did.  I still love the artwork, but have also fallen in love with the characters and the story.  Very enjoyable voicing.  I totally love Fidget (the Nimbat that looks to be a cross of a bat and fox).  There is a very serious and interesting story told, but also lots of fun and humor mixed in.  The fighting which you do a lot of was just fine for me.  Enough challenge to be fun and worthwhile, but not to the point of frustraition.  And the platforming is more exploration and puzzling than having to make pixel-perfect jumps, for which I'm glad.All in all, if this game even looks a little interesting to you, by all means pick it up and have fun.  Even at full price it's not all that much, but on sale it's a no-brainer.

content:
1, 2014
												To start of, the art-style and art-design are extremely beautiful, giving a lot of life to the game. The characters are also very likeable, well written and have good voice-acting. The plot of the game while well written doesn't really do anything too new but the world itself is so deep that it's still very easy to get sucked into the world. You can't talk about this game without mentioning the music. It's extremely well composed and memorable. I'd even say it's worth picking up the soundtrack so you can listen to it whenever you want.As for the gameplay, it's basically a metroidvania, with a lot of the mechanics you would expect from such a game. Something it doesn't have is multiple types weapons but instead a lot of effort was put into the combat to make it more enjoyable. While you don't have that many combos you can perform, you can easily go from one to the next, making the combat really fluent.The only real negative I have is that the ending didn't give a real closure to the characters and ending a game on a low note isn't something you want since that's what the player will remember the most. Still, there's too much to experience from this game for the ending to bring it down.

content:
3, 2016
												When I first saw this game it caught me off guard with the whole side scrolling RPG adventure style, I bought it and played through it from start to finish on hardcore on my first playthrough, it was quite fun with the small flawless challenge. You could die just as easy to enemies as you could kill them, I had my fair share of deaths as well as victories. But I can't deny how beautiful this game is. The unique worlds and weathers that comes with it, biomes and new challenges all around the corner. Characters you can grow to love and hate. You feel feel emmersed in this game as you can't help but feel like Dust. You're thrown into this strange world with no memory or clue as to what's going on or what you're doing. And with a gentle little shove from Ahrah, you're well on your way into a journey around this glorious landcape. I love it's simple yet facinating design and exploration. You can explore places that has NOTHING to do with the main quest line, just to feed that inner adventurer in you or do a good deed. I'm honestly surprised by the amount of potentioal in this game despite being locked in a side scrolling dimension, it still manages to show off so much. It's incredible how well they combined all the genres into this one massive scape. Exploring this beautiful world that surrounds you, filled with details and epic particles. While fending off foes along your journey. You grow close to the characters in this world and really notice the unique traits and personalities. Which makes it so much more emotional for you as you continue onwards. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a challenge, adventure or simply just want to enjoy the beauty some things can offer. The experiences I had from this game will be some I will never forget, I will carry them with me til' the Life Thread calls. And I hope anyone else who sets out on this journey will come to love and hate it as much as I have! Farewell for now though, dust to dust, ashes to ashes.  I've become quite the fanboy, haven't I?

content:
y 18, 2015
Masterpiece.That's what this game is; A masterpiece.* When picking up Action platformers, one of the most important things to me are the controls. This game has extremely satisfying controls; Dashing in the air, dodging attacks, Parrying and pulling off 1000 hit combos. It all feels so damn good.* The thing that stands out the most about Dust: An Elysian Tail is the story. You start the game off as Dust, a swordsmen with no memory of his past or how he got where the game starts off and a companion that seems to know more than he lets off. I wanted to learn more about Dust, and as the game goes on it leads to an epic story of doing what is right.* The music is fantastic, Hyperduck soundworks made a solid soundtrack for this game, I look forward to more of their work. The voice acting is also very good.* Most the characters are very memorable, especially Fidget one of your companions. Fidget certainly made me laugh quite a few times.* The scenery in this game is visually stunning. Everything is hand-painted (which reminded me of Bastion) which made the game a work of art.* The customization is decent enough. When you level you can choose to increase a certain attribute that improves how you play a certain way.* As a final remark, the Final Boss of the game was one of the most epic experiences I have ever had in a video game. I was on the edge of my seat the entire time. It was so well scriped and voice acted. Seriously, this game is worth buying alone JUST for the final boss. Anyways, before I gush too much about this gem you should pick this game up if you like hack and slash platformers. I wish there were more of these kind of games out there. Oh and, don't let the furry characters sway you. When I picked up this game and started playing the first thing that came to my mind was a Disney Movie from my childhood.

content:
7, 2015
												Okay, here's the short version of this review.This game is absolutely AMAZING!!!Now for the long version of this review.Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the most well-crafted video games I have ever played, and it's easily in my top 5 favourite games of all time.  The gameplay is insanely satisfying; any fans of hack-and-slashes or Metroidvanias will most likely enjoy this game big-time.  The story is well-written and surprisingly dark for such a colourful world, and the game puts a lot of emphasis on pretty much every character in the game, even the minor characters!The visuals of this game, in my opinion, might be the best I've ever seen in any video game.  This game's visuals are absolutely BREATHTAKING, especially when the weather effects kick in.  You will not believe how many times I was at a loss of words for how beautiful the game looked at times (you should've seen me when I got to Blackmoor Mountain XD).  As for the soundtrack, it's straight-up majestic.  The OST is beautifully composed, and help capture the mood for pretty much every scene they're assigned.The only complaints that I really have with this game are that the boss fights are pretty meh (with the exception of the game's final boss), but even then, there's so few bosses in the game that it's not a major issue; plus, the characterization given to the bosses is actually really impressive.  The only other issue I have with the game is that Chapter 3 is pretty pointless and, admittedly, kinda boring, but the rest of the game makes up for it in spades.So, long story short, if you have the money for this game and you're just staring at the store page wondering if you should click on that Add to Cart button, I'd say that you should.  Chances are, you will not be disappointed by this game.  I sure wasn't.9.5/10

content:
1
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful game. The art style is so entrancing that it's worth noting how easy it is to get drawn into this world before discussing anything else. Yes, it has anthropomorphic protagonists, but that really shouldn't keep you from giving this game a chance. The combat is tight and fast paced, providing some challenge without ever feeling overwhelming. I was able to get through most of the game without too much trouble fighting enemies, all of which match each location well and build a world you want to explore. I came much closer to 100%-ing the game than I ever planned to, because I had so much fun using the game's many platforming mechanics to explore every inch of each level. There are plenty of collectibles for people who enjoy that kind of thing, but if you'd rather plow through each level and just complete the story, you'll still have a great time. I do want to give the writing some credit here. While I can't say I was particularly surprised by where it led, the game does a great job fleshing out the characters and getting the player invested in uncovering the secrets that hide what really happened in our hero's past (yes, it's an amnesia story. Yes, it goes exactly where you think it will. No, that doesn't hurt your enjoyment of this game). The variety of movement options to explore the map are all fun and rewarding when you pull off each combo just right. I'm still amazed all of this was created by a solo developer. It truly raises the bar for a personal project like this.If I had to give a criticism, I'd say the ending is a pretty harsh difficulty spike. The final boss has multiple steps to it, and the final level is WAY more difficult that anything you've played to that point. It's not brutal, per se, but it does feel like a more gradual curve could have helped brace the player for enemies who know how to block your combos effectively. However, this is the most minor of nitpicks.I loved this game, and if you enjoy story-based adventure/platformers, you'll likely love this too. I couldn't recommend it more highly.

content:

												Dust is a medium sized, hack'n'slash/platformer/RPG with big bucks behind (similar to what got the famous 2012 game, journey).The game graphics are rich and beautiful.  The animation is great. Dust animation is "anime-like" in contrast with the non-playable characters who get a smooth animation. The story is good enough for me. The sound (including voices) and the music (final fantasy-ish) are on the same high level. But I still wonder how they managed to draw such an ugly world map.The gameplay is relatively easy assuming you are patient enough to be grinding XP for levels. The gameplay will be boring/repetitive, because some stages are a bit too long, and many times, suffer from a lack of "density of action". That knowing you will have to re-run many stages several times with different abilities in order to acheive 100% completion... also there, you will be grinding XP for levels in order to make the game clearable.There is a common default in RPGs: either you miss levels and the game is super hard, either you did a lot of boring XP grinding and the game is super easy because you are way over-leveled. So the stages are calibrated to be reasonably clearable at a specific level: if you are below, it's unreasonable, if you are above, it's too easy. This balance issue should be addressed in all RPGs, here it's not the case then you are free to torture yourself like a masochist or get bored at over-leveling your Dust and then slice throught the game like a hot knife in butter.Technically, I got a few bugs (exceptions), and the controls felt slooooow/unresponsive in fight. It does run on linux based OSes with a recent mesa3D.On the overall, I do recommend this game.

ry 8, 2014
												A very fun game, though not a particularly challenging one.Combat is very responsive and flows nicely; almost too nicely since you'll very rarely get hit. I would recommend playing the game on Hardcore difficulty so its at least a little challenging at the start, though it quickly becomes a cake walk anyways once you level up a bit. Later on in the game, after you've torn through thousands of basic enemies, some more interesting enemies start showing up, such as one that can only be hurt by projectile attacks and one that can mimic your aerial dust storm ability. Unfortunately, by that point, you're so ludicrously overpowered, that it doesn't matter, even on hardcore difficulty.But while it's a very easy game, its also a very fun one. You can impale enemies, launch then into the air, then turn into a tornado of slashing chaos and launch into the air before sending the poor creature back down to earth. And then you zap everyone on the screen with lightning.So if you're looking for a challenging game to test your skill against, look somewhere else; but if you just want to pass the time with some fun hack'n'slash action against hordes of hapless opponents, you could certainly do a lot worse than this. And that's really the whole point of video games, isn't it: FUN.

												If you take into account that the one guy spent like... 3 years developing this game... Dust can be the leader of showing how a game should be made. Great story, fun gameplay, Nice voice acting and beautifull scenery and artwork makes this a title well worth the price.The amount of options one has to change settings was unexpected. You can even change the UI layout. I didn't get any bugs which after playing a AAA title game, that had bugs, before this is also a feather in the developers cap. Being a port to linux I was expecting at least one problem.If you are looking for a hack-and-slash platformer then Dust comes highly recommended. It also has some RPG elements which won't have you scratching your head to figure out which stats you need now. Straight forward character upgrades make it easy to choose your gear.This is the first title I played with a controller connected to my PC and I'd recommend everyone to use a controller too. The game was developed for the Xbox 360 anyway.A sure sign that great games/stories/development are still alive. If only more big name publishers could take a page from Dust's book.Do away with the stigma that a good game "must" have the latest GFX, must have a big name publisher behind it and you'll be having FUN again.

												Really really cutesie game, with charming characters, fantastic sceneric level design and mindboggling fire, wind and electrical fights. Although I am the first to admit the fights can get a bit repeating after a good few hours, the rest of the game make more than up for it. I had a really good 12 hours with it, as I am somewhat of an completenist, I bet the less-horder type of gamer should be able to do it in 8 or 9 hours. And even after my 12 ours there were still more secrets and "friends" to discover. Due to a system that gradually gives a way Dust's abilities, old levels gain new possibilities and therefor invite you to do a revisit to discover its hidden treasures. Topping this off by the fact that the creator single handedly draw everything himself makes this game a true masterpiece. Dialoges are okay, even makes you smile here and there and the overall storyline is not to shabby. I would recommend this game for every indie game lover that appreciates the hard work the developer put in it. You can tell its made with love.. And its a controller happy game aswell, so sit back and let it all soak in.  A genorous 8 of 10

												with simplistic graphics and combat, this game has become one of my absolute favorite Story-based games.  Although this game is hugely combat based (it could be argued that it is a brawler) the story is very well synced with that fact.  I absolutely LOVED the story, from start to finish.that aside, what really makes a game is what makes it fun, right?  so, yea..the combat.ohhhh the combat.MY GOD!  IS IT GOOD!This has got to be one of the best 2D combat engines ive ever had the pleasure to play with.  ESPECIALLY for an xbox to pc port game (its never this smooth).  although i find it hard to get into single weapon games, this one did it right by giving you a versatile arsenal of combos and manuevers that make even the cannon fodder fights really fun.  whats more important, though, is that the combat engine is SOOOOO responsive!  i can scarcely believe how much this indie title outclasses so many larger developer titles with its combat engine.IT IS PERFECT.there is plently of room for petty personal complaint, but as far as pure, solid fact goes, the combat in this game does EXACTLY what it's supposed to.  there are zero bugs with it.What I truly love about this game, though; aside from the entrancing story line and exciting combat, is the art.  and take that word loosely, because im talking the whole spectrum.  The animation for character and level design is beautifully done!  The music is absolutely breathtaking!  this game itself, is a work of art as far as videogames go.  It was created and brought to life by one man over 4 years, and you can easily see the passion and talent in his work.this game is much like the older castlevania and metroid games (metrovania?), and in my personal oppinion, if it had been released in that generation (give some modesty to the graphics and sound qualitly, of course) it would have been an instant classic.  There is no circumstance in which i can justify not telling you to buy this game at its current price of $15.  i would easily pay twice that price for a game of this quality.One of the best, most fun games ive played in recent years.

												Yes, yes, yes yes! I loved this game!Like many others have said, combat is indeed boring - it's a very specific style, so unless you're a huge fan of it there isn't much you can do to like it better -, and considering you get to combat quite a lot in a game like this, I was expecting to NOT recommend it, but... everything else was so fiiiiine I didn't even get bored for having to smash the same button over and over. Seriously, look at the screenshots here in the Store. The background is so damn fine you can just keep looking at it forever if you get tired of looking at the monsters getting cut.Combat excluded, this game is flawless.Artwork is GORGEOUS, the way the back and fore grounds blend is beautiful, soundtrack is actually very thought of (for a game of slashing monsters), voice acting is pretty good, writing (dialogs, papers/letters you pick up, story) is amazingly well done (did I mention this was mostly made by a single dude?) and other game mechanics make it up for the combat.There's one point where you get to the snow and it was SO magical. The snow in the ground will "react" in several ways depending if you jumped, if you just walked, if a monster walked, if you moved to attack... This is just one of the little details that made me like this game so much.Also, there's this "extra", which makes you go around freeing your "friends", and at the map you free them, the game changes to copy that friend's game. Like, when you're freeing The Kid from Bastion, you have an empty map that is filled with ground when you walk around, just like in Bastion. Or when you're freeing the little guy from FEZ, your screen gets cut in like 9 pieces all out of place, so you don't know where you'll end up if you walk off the screen. These were great!

content:
r 23, 2013
												Dust is a side scrolling RPG action platformer with surprisingly good aspects for an indie game. You play as Dust, a character weilding an ancient blade while suffering from memory loss. Although the idea has been used many times before, it carries out well for the story. The story itself is unique and I myself enjoyed wondering what could possibly occer next. The envierments range from forests to graveyards, snowy peaks to volcanic regions, all of which vividly colored and highly detailed. The animations for each character are smooth and the character models are great. Each NPC has an interesting personallity that defines them and I must applaud the voice acters for such a wonderful job. The humor is good enough to make me laugh a little, which gives a few lighthearted spots in the middle of all this seriousness. At times, the game will even break the forth wall, such as pointing out how you can pick up a sheep and store it in your inventory. The ending doesn't disappoint and personally left me a bit shaky. The downside of this game is, it's short. I clocked in at 12.2 hours after beating the game and that's doing the main quest, plus some side quests, plus screwing around. However, it's well worth the experiance of playing such an original game.My final rating: 8/10It's a fantasticly done game with little to no glitches and great storyline, however it is short.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2014
												I LOVED this game. This is the first thing I've played since City of Heroes that I really, truly enjoyed. Not only is it gorgeous, but I found the story to be compelling, and I wanted to explore all the areas and find every last scrap of information I could about this world and the people in it. I love the crafting system (find an item, sell it to the merchant, and you never have to farm for it again!) and the combat, which I remapped for ease of use so that I wouldn't have to use the mouse. Did I mention how easy this game is to configure to your personal preferences? The music was okay, if occasionally annoying, and the voice acting was spot-on. The game is a mixture of combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving, and it's challenging but not frustratingly difficult. You do have to return to some areas in order to complete them, as there are sections that can't be reached without abilities gained later in the game, but I didn't find it problematic. The final battle felt epic enough to me to cap off the whole story, and while at first I was disappointed in the ending, my faith was rewarded after all. There are also easter eggs in the form of characters borrowed from other games, which you can encounter and free from captivity and then go hang out with, so that was cool. Overall, there's not much I didn't like about this one, and I'm going to be playing it again!
